{{good article}} [[File:McCulloch Horatio Loch Lomond.jpg|thumb|350px|[[Horatio McCulloch]], ''Loch Lomond'', 1861 |alt=Painting of a lake with fading mountains in background and darker trees in foreground.]] '''Landscape painting in Scotland''' includes all forms of [[Landscape art|painting of landscapes]] in Scotland since its origins in the sixteenth century to the present day. The earliest examples of Scottish landscape painting are in the tradition of [[Scottish Renaissance painted ceilings|Scottish house decoration]] that arose in the sixteenth century. Often said to be the earliest surviving painted landscape created in Scotland is a depiction by the Flemish artist [[Alexander Keirincx]] undertaken for [[Charles I of England|Charles I]].
The [[Capriccio (art)|capriccios]] of Italian and Dutch landscapes undertaken as house decoration by James Norie and his sons in the eighteenth century brought the influence of French artists such as [[Claude Lorrain]] and [[Nicolas Poussin]]. Students of the Nories included [[Jacob More]] whose produced Claudian-inspired landscapes. This period saw a shift in attitudes to the Highlands and mountain landscapes to interpreting them as aesthetically pleasing exemplars of nature. Watercolours were pioneered in Scotland by [[Paul Sandby]] and [[Alexander Runciman]]. [[Alexander Nasmyth]] has been described as "the founder of the Scottish landscape tradition",<ref name=Chilvers2009p433>I. Chilvers, ed., ''The Oxford Dictionary of Art and Artists'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 4th edn., 2009), {{ISBN|0-19-953294-X}}, p. 433.</ref> and produced both urban landscapes and rural scenes that combine Claudian principles of an ideal landscape with the reality of Scottish topography. His students included major landscape painters of the early nineteenth century such as [[Andrew Wilson (artist)|Andrew Wilson]], the watercolourist [[Hugh William Williams]], John Thompson of Duddingston and probably the artists that would be most directly influenced by Nasmyth, John Knox. In the Victorian era, the tradition of Highland landscape painting was continued by figures such as [[Horatio McCulloch]], [[Joseph Farquharson]] and [[William McTaggart]], described as the "Scottish Impressionist". The fashion for coastal painting in the later nineteenth century led to the establishment of artist colonies in places such as [[Pittenweem]] and [[Crail]].
The first significant group of Scottish artists to emerge in the twentieth century were the [[Scottish Colourists]] in the 1920s. They were [[John Duncan Fergusson]], [[Francis Cadell (artist)|Francis Cadell]], [[Samuel Peploe]] and [[George Hunter (painter)|Leslie Hunter]], who placed an emphasis on colour above form. The group of artists connected with Edinburgh, most of whom had studied at [[Edinburgh College of Art]] during or soon after the First World War, became known as [[the Edinburgh School]]. They were influenced by French painters and the [[St. Ives School]] and their art was characterised by use of vivid and often non-naturalistic colour and the use of bold technique above form. Members included [[William George Gillies|William Gillies]], [[John Maxwell (artist)|John Maxwell]], [[William Crozier (Scottish artist)|William Crozier]] and [[William MacTaggart]]. William Johnstone was one of the artists most closely associated with the [[Scottish Renaissance]], an attempt to introduce modernism into art and to create a distinctive national art. [[Stanley Cursiter]] was influenced by the [[Celtic revival]], [[post-impressionism]] and [[futurism (art)|Futurism]]. Later in his career he became a major painter of the coastline of this native Orkney. Other artists strongly influenced by modernism included [[James McIntosh Patrick]] and [[Edward Baird (artist)|Edward Baird]], both of whom were influenced by surrealism and the work of [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder|Bruegel]].
In the post-war period the English-born [[Joan Eardley]] explored the landscapes of the [[Kincardineshire]] coast and created depictions of Glasgow tenements and children in the streets. Scottish artists that continued the tradition of landscape painting and joined the new generation of modernist artists of the highly influential [[St Ives School]] were [[Wilhelmina Barns-Graham]] and [[Margaret Mellis]]. Husband and wife Tom MacDonald and [[Bet Low]] with William Senior formed the [[Clyde Group]], aimed at promoting political art and producing industrial landscapes. [[John Bellany]] focused on the coastal communities of his birth. The coastal theme would also be pursued by artists such as Elizabeth Ogilvy, [[Joyce W. Cairns]] and Ian Stephen.
== Origins to the eighteenth century == {{See also|Scottish art in the eighteenth century}}[[File:KeirincxSetonPalace1638.jpg|thumb|[[Alexander Keirincx]], ''Seton Palace and the Forth Estuary'', c. 1639|alt=Painting of a far view of a Victorian palace estate.]] The earliest examples of Scottish landscape painting are in the tradition of [[Scottish Renaissance painted ceilings|Scottish house decoration]] for burgesses, lairds and lords, that arose after the [[Scottish Reformation|Reformation]] in the sixteenth century, partly as a response to the loss of religious patronage.<ref name=Dawson2007p290>J. E. A. Dawson, ''Scotland Re-Formed, 1488–1587'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2007), {{ISBN|0-7486-1455-9}}, p. 290.</ref> Most were of heraldry, classical myths and allegory, but there were a number of painted landscape scenes.<ref name=Thomas2012pp198-9>A. Thomas, ''The Renaissance'', in T. M. Devine and J. Wormald, ''The Oxford Handbook of Modern Scottish History'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2012), {{ISBN|0-19-162433-0}}, pp. 198–9.</ref> These included the landscapes of four seasons in the ''[[Skelmorlie Aisle]]'' (1638) in the memorial chapel of the Montgomery family in [[Largs]] undertaken by James Stalker ([[Floruit|fl.]] 1632–38). They indicate an awareness of contemporaneous [[Dutch Golden Age painting#Landscapes and cityscapes|Dutch landscape painting]].<ref name=Macmillan1990pp58-61>D. Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'' (Mainstream, 1990), {{ISBN|1-85158-251-7}}, pp. 58–61.</ref> The Flemish artist [[Alexander Keirincx]] (1600–52) was active in England and Scotland where he undertook commissions for [[Charles I of England|Charles I]], mainly of royal castles in Northern England and Scotland. These included one showing [[Seton Palace|Seton House]] (1636–37) in its landscape,<ref name=Macmillan1990p67>Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'', p. 67.</ref> which is often said to be the earliest surviving painted landscape created in Scotland.<ref>J. Holloway and L. Errington, ''The Discovery of Scotland: the Appreciation of Scottish Scenery Through Two Centuries of Painting'' (Edinburgh: National Gallery of Scotland, 1978), p. 1.</ref> The theme of house decoration with landscapes was taken up in the eighteenth century by James Norie (1684–1757), who worked beside the architect [[William Adam (architect)|William Adam]] (1689–1748). Norie, with his sons James (1711–36) and Robert (d. 1766), painted the houses of the peerage with [[Capriccio (art)|capriccios]] or [[pastiche]]s of Italian and Dutch landscapes,<ref name=Baudino2011p153>I. Baudino, "Aesthetics and Mapping the British Identity in Painting", in A. Müller and I. Karremann, ed., ''Mediating Identities in Eighteenth-Century England: Public Negotiations, Literary Discourses, Topography'' (Aldershot: Ashgate, 2011), {{ISBN|1-4094-2618-1}}, p. 153.</ref> bringing to Scotland the influence of French artists such as [[Claude Lorrain]] and [[Nicolas Poussin]]. The Nories were also important figures in professionalisation of Scottish art and the development of art education.<ref name=MacDonald2000pp52-3>M. MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'' (London: Thames and Hudson, 2000), {{ISBN|0-500-20333-4}}, pp. 52–3.</ref>
[[File:JacobMoreNG 1897.jpg|thumb|left|[[Jacob More]], ''The Falls of Clyde: Corra Linn'', c. 1771|alt=Painting of a waterfall with small human figures.]] Probably a student of the Nories was Charles Steuart (fl. 1762–90), who produced a series of [[Perthshire]] landscapes for the Duke of Atholl at [[Blair Castle]], including ''The Black Lynn, Fall on the Brann'' (1766).<ref name=MacDonald2000pp52-3 /> Also among the students of the Nories was [[Jacob More]], who moved to Italy from 1773 and is chiefly known as a landscape painter who created Claudian-style, classically inspired landscapes.<ref name="Baudino2011p153" /> More's series of four paintings "Falls of Clyde" (1771–73), produced before his departure to Italy, have been described by art historian [[Duncan Macmillan (art historian)|Duncan Macmillan]] as treating the waterfalls as "a kind of natural national monument" and has been seen as an early work in developing a [[Romanticism in Scotland|romantic]] sensibility to the Scottish landscape.<ref name=Withers2001pp151-3 /> This period saw a shift in attitudes to the Highlands and mountain landscapes in general, from viewing them as hostile, empty regions occupied by a backwards and marginal people, to interpreting them as aesthetically pleasing exemplars of nature, occupied by rugged primitives, which were now depicted in a dramatic fashion.<ref name=Withers2001pp151-3>C. W. J. Withers, ''Geography, Science and National Identity: Scotland Since 1520'' (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2001), {{ISBN|0-521-64202-7}}, pp. 151–3.</ref> Highly influential in this process was the Scottish philosopher [[Archibald Alison (author)|Archibald Alison]]'s ''Nature and Principles of Taste'' (1790), which widened the forms of landscape seen as appropriate for painting, placing an emphasis on their historical significance and emotional impact on the painter.<ref name=Macmillan1990p219>Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'', p. 219.</ref>
[[Paul Sandby]] (1731–1809), often considered the "father of British watercolour painting",<ref>M. Hargraves, ''Great British Watercolors: From the Paul Mellon Collection at the Yale Center for British Art'' (Yale University Press, 2007), {{ISBN|0-300-11658-6}}, p. 17.</ref> visited Scotland as part of the military survey that followed the [[1745 Jacobite rebellion]] and undertook a number of studies of Scottish scenes.<ref>R. Hewitt, ''Map Of A Nation: A Biography Of The Ordnance Survey'' (Granta Books, 2011), {{ISBN|1-84708-452-4}}.</ref> His abandonment of traditional pen and ink drawing, using washes of colour in order to paint directly in watercolours without pen outlines, opened the way for the creation of powerful Romantic landscapes.<ref>A. Wilton, ''The Great Age of British Watercolours: 1750–1880'' (Prestel Verlag GmbH & Company KG., 1997), {{ISBN|3-7913-1879-9}}.</ref> [[Alexander Runciman]] (1736–1785) was probably the first artist to paint Scottish landscapes in [[watercolour]]s in the more romantic style that was emerging towards the end of the eighteenth century.<ref>E. K. Waterhouse, ''Painting in Britain, 1530 to 1790'' (New Haven, CT: Yale University Press, 5th edn., 1994), {{ISBN|0-300-05833-0}}, p. 293.</ref>
[[File:Alexander Nasmyth - Princes Street with the Commencement of the Building of the Royal Institution - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|right|[[Alexander Nasmyth]], ''Princes Street with the Commencement of the Building of the Royal Institution'', 1825 |alt=Painting of a busy street with on going building construction on right side.]] [[Alexander Nasmyth]] (1758–1840) trained in the Trustees Academy in Edinburgh under Runciman. He visited Italy, where he met with More, and worked in London, but returned to his native Edinburgh for most of his career. He produced work in a large range of forms, including his portrait of Romantic poet [[Robert Burns]], which depicts him against a dramatic Scottish background, but he is chiefly remembered for his landscapes and is described in the ''Oxford Dictionary of Art'' as "the founder of the Scottish landscape tradition".<ref name="Chilvers2009p433" /> He produced both urban landscapes, like ''Edinburgh from Caton Hill'' (1825), which put Edinburgh its geological context, and rural scenes such as ''Castle Huntly and The Tay'' (c. 1800). His works combined Claudian principles of an ideal landscape with the reality of Scottish topography.<ref name=MacDonald2000pp78-81>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 78–81.</ref>
== Nineteenth century == {{See also|Scottish art in the nineteenth century}} Nasmyth was also a highly influential teacher at the Trustee's Academy in Edinburgh. Among his students were painters who took the landscape tradition into the nineteenth century. They included [[Andrew Wilson (artist)|Andrew Wilson]] (1780–1840), who would become Master of the Academy in 1818, the watercolourist [[Hugh William Williams]] (1773–1829), clergyman and artist John Thompson of Duddingston (1778–1840) and probably the artist that would be most directly influenced by Nasmyth, John Knox (1778–1845).<ref name=MacDonald2000pp78-83>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 78–83.</ref> Williams' most famous work are interpretive versions of Greek landscapes, based on sketches taken on his travels there, among them ''The Temple of Poseidon, Cape Sunium'' (1828). His close friend John Thompson focused on a dark dramatic version of Scottish landscape, as in his most famous work ''Fast Castle from Below'' (1824).<ref name=Macmillan1990pp222-5>Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'', pp. 222–5.</ref> Knox directly linked Nasmyth's style with the Romantic literature of [[Walter Scott]].<ref>R. J. Hill, ''Picturing Scotland Through the Waverley Novels: Walter Scott and the Origins of the Victorian Illustrated Novel'' (Aldershot: Ashgate, 2010), {{ISBN|1-4094-7617-0}} , p. 104.</ref> Knox's ''Landscape with Tourists at Lock Katrine'' (c. 1820), was a commentary on the tourist trade that grew up in the [[Trossachs]] in the aftermath of the publication of Scott's poem ''[[The Lady of the Lake (poem)|The Lady of the Lake]]'' in 1810.<ref name=MacDonald2000pp82-3>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 82–83.</ref> He was also among the first artists to take a major interest in depicting the urban landscape of Glasgow.<ref>D. Kemp, ''The Pleasures and Treasures of Britain: A Discerning Traveller's Companion'' (Toronto: Dundurn, 1992), {{ISBN|1-55002-159-1}}, p. 401.</ref> Towards the end of his career he undertook panoramic works of the views from the top of [[Ben Lomond]], which played a part in opening up the Highlands as a spectacle that would be taken up by artists in the second half of the century.<ref name=MacDonald2000pp82-3 />
[[File:McTaggart, The Storm.jpg|thumb|left|[[William McTaggart]], ''The Storm'', 1890 |alt=Painting of a sea shore in a rough weather.]] In the Victorian era, the tradition of Highland landscape painting was continued by figures such as [[Horatio McCulloch]] (1806–67), [[Joseph Farquharson]] (1846–1935) and [[William McTaggart]] (1835–1910).<ref name=Szasz200p136>F. M. Szasz, ''Scots in the North American West, 1790–1917'' (Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press, 2000), {{ISBN|0-8061-3253-1}}, p. 136.</ref> McCulloch was a student of Knox.<ref name=MacDonald2000p104>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', p. 104.</ref> His images of places including [[Glen Coe]], [[Loch Lomond]] and the [[Trossachs]], became parlour room panoramas that defined popular images of Scotland. This was helped by the Queen's declared affection for Scotland, signified by her adoption of [[Balmoral Castle|Balmoral]] as a royal retreat.<ref name=Billcliffe2009p27>R. Billcliffe, ''The Glasgow Boys'' (London: Frances Lincoln, 2009), {{ISBN|0-7112-2906-6}}, p. 27.</ref> The wildlife around Balmoral was immortalised by English painter [[Edwin Landseer]] (1802–73) in the much copied ''[[Monarch of the Glen (painting)|Monarch of the Glen]]'' (1851).<ref name=MacDonald2000p105>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', p. 105.</ref> In this period a Scottish "grand tour" developed with large number of English artists, including [[J. M. W. Turner|Turner]], flocking to the Highlands to paint and draw.<ref name=Billcliffe2009p27 /> From the 1870s Farquharson was a major figure in interpreting Scottish landscapes, specialising in snowscapes and sheep, and using a mobile heated studio in order to capture the conditions from life.<ref name=Szasz200p136 /> In the same period McTaggart emerged as the leading Scottish landscape painter. He has been compared with [[John Constable]] and described as the "Scottish Impressionist", with free brushwork often depicting stormy seas and moving clouds.<ref name=Chilvers2009p376>Chilvers, ''The Oxford Dictionary of Art and Artists'', p. 376.</ref> The fashion for coastal painting in the later nineteenth century led to the establishment of artist colonies in places such as [[Pittenweem]] and [[Crail]] in Fife,<ref>P. Howard, ''Landscapes: the Artists' Vision'' (London: Taylor & Francis, 1991), {{ISBN|0-415-00775-5}}, p. 116.</ref> [[Cockburnspath]] in the Borders, [[Cambuskenneth]] near Stirling on the River Forth<ref>N. Lubbren, ''Rural Artists' Colonies in Europe: 1870–1910'' (Manchester University Press, 2001), {{ISBN|0-7190-5867-8}}, p. 165.</ref> and [[Kirkudbright]] in Dumfries and Galloway.<ref>P. Bourne, ''Kirkcudbright 100 Years of an Artists' Colony'' (Atelier Books, 2003), {{ISBN|1-873830-13-0}}.</ref> The [[Glasgow Boys]] emerged in the 1880s, rejecting much of the sentimentality of Scottish landscape painting and introducing elements of impressionism. Key figures included [[William York Macgregor|W. Y. Macgregor]] (1855–1923), [[James Guthrie (artist)|James Guthrie]] (1859–1930), [[John Lavery]] (1856–1941), [[George Henry (painter)|George Henry]] (1858–1943) and [[E. A. Walton]] (1860–1922).<ref>A. Gray, ''A History of Scotland: Modern times. Book five'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1989), {{ISBN|0-19-917063-0}}, p. 43.</ref>{{clear}}
== Twentieth century to today == {{See also|Art in modern Scotland}} [[File:Samuel Peploe, Iona, 1933.jpg|thumb|right|[[Samuel Peploe]], ''Ben More seen from Iona'', 1927 |alt=Painting of a blue water body with mountains in background.]] The first significant group of Scottish artists to emerge in the twentieth century were the [[Scottish Colourists]] in the 1920s. The name was later given to four artists who knew each other and exhibited together, but did not form a cohesive group. All had spent time in France between 1900 and 1914<ref name=Chilvers2009p575>Chilvers, ''The Oxford Dictionary of Art and Artists'', p. 575.</ref> and all looked for inspiration to Paris, particularly to the [[Fauvism|Fauvists]], such as [[Monet]], [[Matisse]] and [[Cézanne]], whose techniques they combined with the painting traditions of Scotland.<ref>{{Citation |author= |contribution= |date= |title=The Scottish Colourists |journal=Explore Art |editor= |edition= |isbn= |issn= |volume= |pages= |place= |publisher= |url=http://www.exploreart.co.uk/results.asp?SF1=art_style&ST1=The%20Scottish%20Colourists&SORT=sort_name |accessdate=12 November 2012 |authorlink= |archiveurl=http://www.exploreart.co.uk/results.asp?SF1=art_style&ST1=The%20Scottish%20Colourists&SORT=sort_name |archivedate=12 November 2012 }}</ref> They were [[John Duncan Fergusson]] (1874–1961), [[Francis Cadell (artist)|Francis Cadell]] (1883–1937), [[Samuel Peploe]] (1871–1935) and [[George Hunter (painter)|Leslie Hunter]] (1877–1931).<ref name=visit>{{Citation |author= |contribution= |date=|title=The Scottish Colourists |journal=Visit Scotland.com |editor= |edition= |isbn= |issn= |volume= |pages= |place= |publisher= |url=http://www.visitscotland.com/repository/library/932636/1000635/colourists |accessdate=7 May 2010 |authorlink= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080429020605/http://www.visitscotland.com/repository/library/932636/1000635/colourists |archivedate=29 April 2008}}</ref> They have been described as the first Scottish modern artists and were the major mechanism by which [[post-impressionism]] reached Scotland.<ref name=Chilvers2009p575 /> From 1912 Cadell visited [[Iona]] annually to paint and he was joined there by Peploe from 1920. They produced a number of works using the west-coast light and Iona landscape, particularly views of [[Ben More (Mull)|Ben More]], which both painted several times. [[John Duncan (painter)|John Duncan]], the arts and crafts artist, was still active in the early twentieth century and painted several landscapes similar in style to those of Cadell and Peploe.<ref name=MacDonald2000p162>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', p. 162.</ref> Hunter used a vibrant palette to create notable paintings of the landscape around [[Balloch, Highland|Balloch]] on Loch Lomond.<ref name=MacDonald2000pp163-4>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 163–4.</ref> Leading architect [[Charles Rennie Mackintosh]] (1868–1928) abandoned architecture for painting after World War I and created a number of landscapes, particularly of southern France. He became associated with Fergusson, who pursued also experimental landscape in the inter-war years, many of which were around his home in the Highlands, like that at ''Craigcornash'' (c. 1925). The work of Mackintosh and Fergusson has similarities to that of [[David Young Cameron]] (1865–1945) who pursued the systematic painting of the Highlands in his later years.<ref name=MacDonald2000p178>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', p. 178.</ref>
The group of artists connected with Edinburgh, most of whom had studied at [[Edinburgh College of Art]] during or soon after the First World War, became known as [[the Edinburgh School]].<ref name=EdinburghGalleriesEdinbrughSchool>[http://www.edinburghmuseums.org.uk/Venues/City-Art-Centre/Collections/Fine-Art/Scottish-Art-Movements/The-Edinburgh-School "The Edinburgh School"], Edinburgh Museums and Galleries, retrieved 10 April 2013.</ref> They were influenced by French painters and the [[St. Ives School]]<ref name=Macmillan2011>D. Macmillan, "Culture: modern times 1914–", in M. Lynch, ed., ''Oxford Companion to Scottish History'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2011), {{ISBN|0-19-969305-6}}, pp. 153–4.</ref> and their art was characterised by use of vivid and often non-naturalistic colour and the use of bold technique above form.<ref name=EdinburghGalleriesEdinbrughSchool /> Members included [[William George Gillies|William Gillies]] (1898–1973), who worked in both watercolours and oils around [[Ardnamurchan]] and [[Morar]] in the 1930s, [[John Maxwell (artist)|John Maxwell]] (1905–62) whose landscapes were influenced by mythological themes,<ref name=MacDonald2000pp182-3>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 182–3.</ref> [[William Crozier (Scottish artist)|William Crozier]] (1893–1930), whose landscapes were created with glowing colours and [[William MacTaggart]] (1903–81), grandson of the nineteenth-century artist, noted for his landscapes of East Lothian, France and Norway.<ref name=EdinburghGalleriesEdinbrughSchool /> His ''Celebration of Earth, Air, Fire and Water'' (1978) utilised the Borders' landscape in abstract form.<ref name=MacDonald2000p184>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', p. 184.</ref>
[[File:WilliamCrozier, Edinburgh from Salisbury Crags.jpg|thumb|left|[[William Crozier (Scottish artist)|William Crozier]], ''Edinburgh from Salisbury Crags'', c. 1933 |alt=Painting of far view of a town with various building seen.]] William Johnstone (1897–1981) was one of the artists most closely associated with the [[Scottish Renaissance]], an attempt to introduce modernism into art and to create a distinctive national art. He studied cubism, surrealism and was introduced to new American art by his wife the sculptor Flora Macdonald. He moved towards [[Abstract art|abstraction]], attempting to utilise aspects of landscape, poetry and Celtic art. His most significant work, ''A Point in Time'' (1929–38), has been described by art historian Duncan Macmillan as "one of the most important Scottish pictures of the century and one of the most remarkable pictures by any British painter in the period".<ref>Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'', {{ISBN|0-500-20333-4}}, pp. 351–2.</ref><ref name=Gardiner2005p173>M. Gardiner, ''Modern Scottish Culture'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2005), {{ISBN|0-7486-2027-3}}, p. 173.</ref><ref>D. Macmillan, [http://www.scotsman.com/the-scotsman/scotland/review-painters-in-parallel-william-johnstone-william-gillies-1-2063707 "Review: Painters in Parallel: William Johnstone & William Gillies"], ''Scotsman.com'', 19 January 2012, retrieved 8 May 2012.</ref> [[Stanley Cursiter]] (1887–1976) was influenced by the [[Celtic revival]], post-impressionism and [[futurism (art)|Futurism]]. Later in his career he became a major painter of the coastline of this native Orkney.<ref name="MacDonald2000pp163-4" /><ref name=Gardiner2005p173 /> Other artists strongly influenced by modernism included [[James McIntosh Patrick]] (1907–98) and [[Edward Baird (artist)|Edward Baird]] (1904–49).<ref name=Gardiner2005p173 /> Both trained in Glasgow, but spent most of their careers in and around their respective native cities of Dundee and Montrose. Both were influenced by surrealism and the work of [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder|Bruegel]] and focused on landscape, as can be seen in McIntosh Patrick's ''Traquair House'' (1938) and more overtly in Baird's ''The Birth of Venus'' (1934).<ref>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 175–6.</ref>
In the post-war period the English-born [[Joan Eardley]] (1921–63) moved to Glasgow, where she was a graduate of the [[Glasgow School of Art]] and explored the landscapes of the [[Kincardineshire]] coast and created depictions of Glasgow tenements and children in the streets.<ref>MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', pp. 191–2.</ref> Scottish artists that continued the tradition of landscape painting and joined the new generation of modernist artists of the highly influential St Ives School were [[Wilhelmina Barns-Graham]] (1912–2004) and [[Margaret Mellis]] (1914–2009).<ref name="MacDonald2000p193">MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'', p. 193.</ref> Polish [[Realism (arts)|realist]] [[Josef Herman]] (1911–2000) was resident in Glasgow between 1940 and 1943<ref name=Macmillan1990pp370-1>Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'', pp. 370–1.</ref> where he influenced husband and wife Tom MacDonald (1914–1985) and Bet Low (born 1924), who with painter William Senior (born 1927) formed the Clyde Group, aimed at promoting political art. Their work included industrial and urban landscapes such as MacDonald's ''Transport Depot'' (1944–45) and Bet Low's ''Blochairn Steelworks'' (c. 1946).<ref name=Macmillan1990pp370-1 /> [[John Bellany]] (born 1942), mainly focusing on the coastal communities of his birth, labelled "Scottish realism", was among the leading Scottish intellectuals from the 1960s.<ref>C. Richardson, ''Scottish Art Since 1960: Historical Reflections and Contemporary Overviews'' (Aldershot: Ashgate, 2011), {{ISBN|0-7546-6124-5}}, p. 58.</ref> Landscape has remained a major form in Scottish painting in the work of artists such as James Morrison (born 1932), Ian MacKenzie Smith (born 1935), Duncan Shanks (born 1937) and [[Barbara Rae]] (born 1943).<ref name=Macmillan1990p400>Macmillan, ''Scottish Art, 1460–1990'', p. 400.</ref> The coastal theme would also be pursued by artists such as Elizabeth Ogilvy (born 1946), [[Joyce W. Cairns]] (born 1947) and Ian Stephen (born 1955).<ref name="MacDonald2000p193" />

{{Infobox Artwork | image=Annibale Carracci 003.jpg | image_size=350px | title=Landscape with the Flight into Egypt | artist=Annibale Carracci | year=c. 1604 | medium=Oil on canvas | height_metric=122 | width_metric=230 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=Rome | museum=[[Galleria Doria Pamphilj]] }} '''''Landscape with the Flight into Egypt''''' is a painting by the [[Italy|Italian]] [[Baroque]] painter [[Annibale Carracci]]. Dating from c. 1604, it remains in the palace for which it was painted in [[Rome]] as part of the collection of the [[Galleria Doria Pamphilj]].
The painting, depicting the biblical New Testament event of the ''[[Flight into Egypt]]'', was commissioned in 1603 by Cardinal [[Pietro Aldobrandini]] for the family chapel in his palace in Rome, later known as [[Palazzo Doria Pamphilj]]. The commission includes six paintings in six [[lunette]]s, which were executed by Carracci and his pupils (including [[Francesco Albani]], [[Domenichino]] and [[Giovanni Lanfranco]]).<ref>Martin, 317</ref>
The work is frequently regarded as a key work in Baroque [[landscape painting]] and is the "most celebrated example" of the "new landscape style" Carracci developed in Rome of "carefully constructed landscape panoramas", according to [[Rudolf Wittkower]].<ref>Wittkower, 70</ref> For [[John Rupert Martin]] it is "the archetypal classical landscape, later to be emulated with variations by Domenichino, [[Nicolas Poussin|Poussin]] and [[Claude Lorrain|Claude]] ... the small scale of the figures in relation to the spacious natural setting at once establishes a new priority in which landscape takes first place and history second";<ref>Martin, 60</ref> though insofar as it is "new", that is for Italian painting, as such works had been common in Northern painting since [[Joachim Patinir]] began to use the same reversal of scale almost a century before. The journey of the [[Holy Family]] is echoed by other moving elements including the sheep, birds, cows and the camels on the ridge at left.<ref>Martin, 176</ref>
Wittkower sees in it "a heroic and aristocratic conception of Nature tamed and ennobled by the presence of man", as such works always contain a large man-made feature, here the castle "severely composed of horizontals and verticals" under which the party moves. They are placed at the meeting of two diagonals represented by the sheep and the river, "thus figures and buildings are intimately blended with the carefully arranged pattern of the landscape".<ref>Wittkower, 70</ref>
[[Kenneth Clark]] mentions the work as an example of the "ideal landscape" driven to promote itself in the [[hierarchy of genres]] by emulating (in the absence of much evidence of what classical landscape painting was like) an essentially literary vision, largely derived from the pastoral poems of [[Virgil]]: "the features of which it is composed must be chosen from nature, as poetic diction is chosen from ordinary speech, for their elegance, their ancient associations, and their faculty of harmonious combination. ''[[Ut pictura poesis]]''".<ref>Clark, 67</ref> Clark's praise of the work is noticeably faint, as it lacks the spirit he finds in [[Giorgione]] and Claude in the same tradition: "At their best, as in the lunettes in the Doria Gallery, Annibale Carracci's landscapes are admirable pieces of picture-making, in which agreeably stylized parts are built up into a harmonious whole. We recognize the science which has gone into the construction of the castle in the centre of the ''Flight into Egypt''... But in the end these eclectic landscapes are of interest only to historians".<ref>Clark, 74; see the rest of the chapter for more whole-hearted praise of Giorgione and Claude.</ref>
