[[Walt Disney Studios (division)|Walt Disney Studios]] |leader_title = Chairman |leader_name = [[Charles Rivkin]] | leader_title2 = CEO | leader_name2 = [[Charles Rivkin]] |website = {{URL|www.mpaa.org}} }} The '''Motion Picture Association of America''' ('''MPAA''') is an American [[trade association]] representing the [[Major film studio#Current|six major film studios]] of [[Cinema of the United States|Hollywood]]. Founded in 1922 as the '''Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America''' ('''MPPDA'''), its original goal was to ensure the viability of the American film industry. In addition, the MPAA established guidelines for film content which resulted in the creation of the [[Motion Picture Production Code|Production Code]] in 1930. This code, also known as the Hays Code, was replaced by a voluntary [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|film rating system]] in 1968, which is managed by the Classification and Rating Administration (CARA). More recently, the MPAA has advocated for the [[Film|motion picture]] and [[television]] industry, with the goals of promoting effective copyright protection, reducing [[Copyright infringement#"Piracy"|piracy]], and expanding market access. It has long worked to curb [[copyright infringement]], including recent attempts to limit the sharing of [[copyright]]ed works via [[peer-to-peer]] [[file-sharing]] networks and by streaming from pirate sites. Former United States Ambassador to France [[Charles Rivkin]] is the current chairman and CEO of the MPAA. ==History== ===Foundation and early history: 1922–29=== The MPAA was founded as the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America (MPPDA) in 1922 as a [[trade association]] of member motion picture companies. At its founding, MPPDA member companies produced approximately 70 to 80 percent of the films made in the United States.{{cite news |title=Ultimatum by Hays to Purify Movies |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1922/06/05/archives/ultimatum-by-hays-to-purify-movies-producers-and-distrihuters-join.html |work=The New York Times |date=5 June 1922 |accessdate=1 February 2013}} Former [[United States Postmaster General|Postmaster General]] [[Will H. Hays]] was named the association's first president.{{cite book |title=The Dame in the Kimono: Hollywood, Censorship, and the Production Code |last1=Leff |first1=Leonard J. |last2=Simmons |first2=Jerold L. |year=2001 |publisher=University Press of Kentucky |location= |isbn=0813190118 |page= |pages= |url= }} The main focus of the MPPDA in its early years was on producing a strong public relations campaign to ensure that [[Hollywood]] remained financially stable and able to attract investment from [[Wall Street]], while simultaneously ensuring that American films had a "clean moral tone".{{cite news |title=Hays Attacks Censors; Says Film Men O.K. |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EhdLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IiENAAAAIBAJ&dq=motion%20picture%20producers%20and%20distributors%20of%20america&pg=2733%2C7216162 |work=The Evening News |date=26 May 1922 |accessdate=1 February 2013}} The MPPDA also instituted a code of conduct for Hollywood's actors in an attempt to govern their behavior offscreen. Finally, the code sought to protect American film interests abroad by encouraging film studios to avoid racist portrayals of foreigners.{{cite news |title=Czar of Movies Hits Censorship |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Np5XAAAAIBAJ&sjid=t_MDAAAAIBAJ&dq=motion%20picture%20producers%20and%20distributors%20of%20america&pg=5826%2C734859 |work=The Spokesman-Review |date=25 January 1924 |accessdate=1 February 2013}} From the early days of the association, Hays spoke out against public [[Censorship in the United States#Film censorship|censorship]],{{cite news |title=Hays Says Public Censors Will Fail |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1922/07/25/archives/hays-says-public-censors-will-fail-declares-american-principle-of.html |work=The New York Times |date=25 July 1922 |accessdate=1 February 2013}} and the MPPDA worked to raise support from the general public for the film industry's efforts against such censorship.{{cite news |title=Will Hays, Pledging Motion Picture Industry to Clean Pictures, Asks Public to Aid War on Evil Films |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WFBbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QVANAAAAIBAJ&dq=motion%20picture%20producers%20and%20distributors%20of%20america&pg=4100%2C1398046 |work=Providence News |date=6 July 1922 |accessdate=1 February 2013}} Large portions of the public opposed censorship, but also decried the lack of morals in movies. At the time of the MPPDA's founding, there was no national censorship, but some state and municipal laws required movies to be censored, a process usually oveseen by a local censorship board. Thus, in certain locations in the U.S., films were often edited to comply with local laws regarding the onscreen portrayal of violence and sexuality, among other topics. This resulted in negative publicity for the studios and decreasing numbers of theater goers, who were uninterested in films that were sometimes so severely edited that they were incoherent. In 1929, more than 50 percent of American moviegoers lived in a location overseen by such a board. In 1924, Hays instituted "The Formula", a loose set of guidelines for filmmakers, in an effort to get the movie industry to self-regulate the issues that the censorship boards had been created to address. "The Formula" requested that studios send synopses of films being considered to the MPPDA for review. This effort largely failed, however, as studios were under no obligation to send their scripts to Hays's office, nor to follow his recommendations.{{cite book |author=Gregory D. Black |title=Hollywood Censored: Morality Codes, Catholics, and the Movies |year=1996 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=0521565928 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ybKqnNNR7hwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Hollywood+Censored:+Morality+Codes,+Catholics,+and+the+Movies&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hIweUZuEJsHe0QG6zoHgBg&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA |accessdate=15 February 2013}} In 1927, Hays oversaw the creation of a code of "Don'ts and Be Carefuls" for the industry. This list outlined the issues that movies could encounter in different localities. Hays also created a Studio Relations Department (SRD) with staff available to the studios for script reviews and advice regarding potential problems. Again, despite Hays' efforts, studios largely ignored the "Don'ts and Be Carefuls," and by the end of 1929, the MPPDA received only about 20 percent of Hollywood scripts prior to production, and the number of regional and local censorship boards continued to increase. ===Production Code: 1930–34=== In 1930, the MPPDA introduced the [[Motion Picture Production Code|Production Code]], sometimes called the "Hays Code". The Code consisted of moral guidelines regarding what was acceptable to include in films.{{cite news |title=Movie Industry to Bar Obscenity and Crime Scenes, Plan |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-K9FAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Pb0MAAAAIBAJ&dq=motion%20picture%20producers%20and%20distributors%20of%20america&pg=3907%2C1202519 |work=The Telegraph-Herald and Times-Journal |date=2 April 1930 |accessdate=1 February 2013}} Unlike the "Dont's and Be Carefuls", which the studios had ignored, the Production Code was endorsed by studio executives. The Code incorporated many of the "Don'ts and Be Carefuls" as specific examples of what could not be portrayed. Among other rules, the code prohibited inclusion of "scenes of passion" unless they were essential to a film's plot; "pointed profanity" in either word or action; "sex perversion"; justification or explicit coverage of adultery; sympathetic treatment of crime or criminals; dancing with "indecent" moves; and white slavery.{{cite news |title=Producers Adopt Code of Conduct For Screen Shows |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WyRkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WHsNAAAAIBAJ&dq=motion%20picture%20producers%20and%20distributors%20of%20america&pg=3606%2C4315324 |work=The Calgary Daily Herald |date=1 April 1930 |accessdate=1 February 2013}} Because studio executives had been involved in the decision to adopt the code, MPPDA-member studios were more willing to submit scripts for consideration. However, the growing economic impacts of the [[Great Depression]] of the early 1930s increased pressure on studios to make films that would draw the largest possible audiences, even if it meant taking their chances with local censorship boards by disobeying the Code. In 1933 and 1934 the [[National Legion of Decency|Catholic Legion of Decency]], along with a number of Protestant and women's groups, launched plans to boycott films that they deemed immoral.{{cite book |author=Matthew Bernstein |title=Controlling Hollywood: Censorship and Regulation in the Studio Era |year=2000 |isbn=0813527074 |publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dEYoT857G8UC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Controlling+Hollywood:+Censorship+and+Regulation+in+the+Studio+Era&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eIseUamHDaa00AHX1oH4Bg&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA |accessdate=15 February 2013}} In order to avert boycotts which might further harm the profitability of the film industry, the MPPDA created a new department, the [[Production Code Administration]] (PCA), with [[Joseph Breen]] as its head. Unlike previous attempts at self-censorship, PCA decisions were binding—no film could be exhibited in an American theater without a stamp of approval from the PCA, and any producer attempting to do so faced a fine of $25,000. After ten years of unsuccessful voluntary codes and expanding local censorship boards, the studio approved and agreed to enforce the codes, and the nationwide "Production Code" was enforced starting on July 1, 1934. ===War years: 1935–45=== In the years that immediately followed the adoption of the Code, Breen often sent films back to Hollywood for additional edits, and in some cases, simply refused to issue PCA approval for a film to be shown.{{cite news |title=Pictures Purged |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-Z5fAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wzEMAAAAIBAJ&dq=motion%20picture%20producers%20and%20distributors%20of%20america&pg=3861%2C4395343 |work=Lewiston Morning Tribune |date=15 July 1934 |accessdate=1 February 2013}} At the same time, Hays promoted the industry's new focus on wholesome films{{cite news |title=Newest Pictures Based on Classics |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=atRXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_fQDAAAAIBAJ&dq=motion%20picture%20producers%20and%20distributors%20of%20america&pg=2505%2C6402892 |work=Spokane Daily Chronicle |date=26 March 1935 |accessdate=1 February 2013}} and continued promoting American films abroad.{{cite news |title=Will Hays Gets Italy to Lift Film Blockage |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PHYxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_yEEAAAAIBAJ&dq=will-hays&pg=6885%2C5924504 |work=The Milwaukee Journal |date=25 November 1936 |accessdate=19 February 2013}} For nearly three years, studios complied with the Code. By 1938, however, as the threat of war in Europe loomed, movie producers began to worry about the possibility of decreased profits abroad. This led to a decreased investment in following the strictures of the code, and occasional refusals to comply with PCA demands. That same year, responding to trends in European films in the run-up to the war, Hays spoke out against using movies as a vehicle for [[propaganda]].{{cite news |title=Hays Scores Propaganda On Screens |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LE0bAAAAIBAJ&sjid=D0wEAAAAIBAJ&dq=motion%20picture%20producers%20and%20distributors%20of%20america&pg=4508%2C6029095 |work=The Pittsburgh Press |date=30 March 1938 |accessdate=1 February 2013}} In 1945, after 24 years as president, Hays stepped down from his position at the MPPDA, although he continued to act as an advisor for the Association for the next five years.{{cite news |title=Eric Johnston to Rule Movies |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vipWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=o-QDAAAAIBAJ&dq=will-hays%20and%20johnston&pg=6105%2C4697631 |work=The Spokesman-Review |date=20 September 1945 |accessdate=19 February 2013}} ===Johnston era: 1945–63=== In 1945 the MPPDA hired [[Eric Johnston]], four-time president of the [[United States Chamber of Commerce]], to replace Hays.{{cite news |title=Johnston Named Motion Picture Czar |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7NZYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jvUDAAAAIBAJ&dq=will-hays%20and%20johnston&pg=6668%2C3421898 |work=Spokane Daily Chronicle |date=19 September 1945 |accessdate=19 February 2013}} During his first year as president, Johnston rebranded the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America as the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA). He also created the Motion Picture Export Association (MPEA) to promote American films abroad by opposing production company monopolies in other countries.{{cite book |author=Jon Lewis |title=Hollywood V. Hard Core: How the Struggle Over Censorship Saved the Modern Film Industry |year=2002 |isbn=0814751423 |publisher=NYU Press |pages=37–38 }}{{cite news |title=Movies Begin to Fight Foreign Monopolies |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1946/04/05/archives/movies-begin-to-fight-foreign-monopolies.html |work=New York Times |date=5 April 1946 |accessdate=12 April 2013}} In 1947 the MPEA voted to discontinue film shipments to Britain after the British government imposed an import tax on American films.{{cite news |title=Film Group Votes Ban On Movies for England |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MggpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nU0DAAAAIBAJ&dq=mpaa%20johnston&pg=6849%2C767130 |work=The Deseret News |date=7 August 1947 |accessdate=12 April 2013}} Johnston negotiated with the British government to end the tax in 1948, and film shipments resumed.{{cite news |title=MPEA Approves Johnston's Agreement; To Lift Film Embargo After British Ratify |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1948/03/19/archives/mpea-approves-johnstons-agreement-to-lift-film-embargo-after.html |work=New York Times |date=19 March 1948 |accessdate=16 April 2013}} In 1956, Johnston oversaw the first major revision of the Production Code since it was created in 1930. This revision allowed the treatment of some subjects which had previously been forbidden, including abortion and the use of narcotics, so long as they were "within the limits of good taste". At the same time, the revisions added a number of new restrictions to the code, including outlawing the depiction of blasphemy and mercy killings in films.{{cite news |title=Motion Picture Code Made 'More Flexible' |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JRFWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cOIDAAAAIBAJ&dq=mpaa%20johnston&pg=6763%2C3434436 |work=Eugene Register Guard |date=17 December 1956 |accessdate=12 April 2013}} Johnston was well-liked by studio executives, and his political connections helped him function as an effective liaison between Hollywood and Washington.{{cite book |author=Jack Valenti |title=This Time, This Place |year=2007 |isbn=9780307346650 |publisher=Three Rivers Press |location=New York |page=271 }} In 1963, while still serving as president of the MPAA, Johnston died of a stroke.{{cite news |title=Eric Johnston Dies at 66 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uJtPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sVIDAAAAIBAJ&dq=eric-johnston&pg=2746%2C970120 |work=St. Petersburg Times |date=23 August 1963 |accessdate=12 April 2013}} For three years, the MPAA operated without a president while studio executives searched for a replacement.{{cite web|url=http://mpaa.org/about/history |title=History of the MPAA |work=MPAA.org |publisher=Motion Picture Association of America |accessdate=23 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130621235047/http://www.mpaa.org/about/history |archivedate=June 21, 2013 }} ===Valenti era: 1966–2004=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | image1 = JackValenti19.JPG | width1 = 220 | caption1 = Jack Valenti was the president of Motion Picture Association of America for 38 years. | image2 = | width2 = 220 | caption2 = Former U.S. Ambassador to France and Assistant Secretary of State Charles Rivkin became the chairman and CEO of the MPAA in 2017 }} The MPAA hired [[Jack Valenti]], former aide to President [[Lyndon B. Johnson|Lyndon Johnson]], as president of the MPAA in 1966.{{cite news |title=Valenti retires, Glickman named Hollywood's Washington man |author=Jeff Clabaugh |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/stories/2004/06/28/daily27.html?page=all |work=Washington Business Journal |date=1 July 2004 |accessdate=2 April 2013}} In 1968, Valenti replaced the Production Code with [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|a system of voluntary film ratings]], in order to limit censorship of Hollywood films and provide parents with information about the appropriateness of films for children.{{cite book |author=Jack Valenti |title=This Time, This Place |year=2007 |isbn=9780307346650 |publisher=Three Rivers Press |location=New York |pages=302–306 }} In addition to concerns about protecting children,{{cite news |title=Film Ratings System Adopted By Industry |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=U4dQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PlwDAAAAIBAJ&dq=mpaa%20film%20ratings%20system&pg=5849%2C5695295 |work=St. Petersburg Times |date=8 October 1968 |accessdate=12 March 2013}} Valenti stated in his autobiography that he sought to ensure that American filmmakers could produce the films they wanted, without the censorship that existed under the Production Code that had been in effect since 1934. In 1975 Valenti established the Film Security Office, an anti-piracy division at the MPAA, which sought to recover unauthorized recordings of films to prevent duplication.{{cite news |title=Movie industry fights film piracy |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HUU_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=DVIMAAAAIBAJ&dq=jack%20valenti%20piracy&pg=2594%2C4176001 |work=[[Windsor Star]] |date=14 April 1975 |accessdate=18 April 2013}} Valenti continued to fight piracy into the 1980s, asking Congress to install chips in VCRs that would prevent illegal reproduction of video cassettes,{{cite news |title=Movie Producers Want Anti-Copy Device On VCR Makers |author=Bill McCloskey |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=3SJD-HRB0-0011-83BF&csi=304478&oc=00240&perma=true |work=The Associated Press |date=23 September 1986 |accessdate=6 March 2013}} and in the 1990s supported law enforcement efforts to stop [[bootleg recording|bootleg]] distribution of video tapes.{{cite news |title=MPAA Bags Some 50,000 Bogus Vids in N.Y. Bust |author=Paul Verna |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=3SJD-WP60-002S-H0VG&csi=5545&oc=00240&perma=true |work=Billboard |date=18 May 1991 |accessdate=6 March 2013}} Valenti also oversaw a major change in the ratings system that he had helped create—the removal of the "X" rating, which had come to be closely associated with pornography. It was replaced with a new rating, "NC-17", in 1990.{{cite news |title=How the X Got Axed |author1=Melina Gerosa |author2=Anne Thompson |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,318334,00.html |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=12 October 1990 |accessdate=18 April 2013}}{{cite news |title=Big-name Hollywood directors join battle over MPAA |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=01lYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BPoDAAAAIBAJ&dq=valenti%20mpaa&pg=7058%2C4089237 |work=[[The Spokesman-Review|Spokane Chronicle]] |date=31 July 1990 |accessdate=18 April 2013}} In 2001 Valenti established the Digital Strategy Department at the MPAA to specifically address issues surrounding [[digital cinema|digital film]] distribution and piracy.{{cite news |title=Jack Valenti Steps Down from MPAA/MPA |author=Guy Wright |work=Digital Producer Magazine |date=1 July 2004 }} ===Modern era: 2004–present=== After serving as president of the MPAA for 38 years, Valenti announced that he would step down in 2004.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3861263.stm |title=Hollywood chief Valenti to retire |date=2 July 2004 |work=BBC |accessdate=2 April 2013}} In September of that year, he was replaced by former [[United States Secretary of Agriculture|Secretary of Agriculture]] [[Dan Glickman]]. During his tenure, Glickman focused on tax issues, content protection efforts, and increasing U.S. studios' access to international markets.{{cite news |title=Glickman says he'll step down in 2010 |author=Anne Schroeder Mullins |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/news/politics-politico/glickman-says-hell-step-down-in-2010-362652/ |work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |date=19 October 2009 |accessdate=2 April 2013}} He led lobbying efforts that resulted in $400 million in federal tax incentives for the movie industry, and also supported a law which created federal oversight of anti-piracy efforts.{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/oct/20/business/fi-ct-glickman20 |title=Search starts for MPAA chief Dan Glickman's replacement |author1=Jim Puzzanghera |author2=Claudia Eller |date=20 October 2009 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=16 April 2013}} Glickman stepped down in 2010.{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1023_3-10439572-93.html |title=MPAA's Dan Glickman steps down |author=Greg Sandoval |date=22 January 2010 |work=CNET |accessdate=2 April 2013}} After a search which lasted over a year, the MPAA hired former U.S. Senator [[Chris Dodd]] to replace Glickman in March 2011.{{cite news |title=MPAA hires former Sen. Dodd as head |author1= Richard Verrier |author2=Jim Puzzanghera |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/mar/02/business/la-fi-ct-mpaa-dodd-20110302 |work=Los Angeles Times |date=2 March 2011 |accessdate=2 April 2013}} In his role as president, Dodd focused on content protection, trade, and improving Hollywood's image.{{cite news |title=MPAA Chief Christopher Dodd Says SOPA Debate Isn't Over, Defends Hosting Harvey Weinstein Even as He Attacked Over 'Bully' |author=Pamela McClintock |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/mpaa-christopher-dodd-sopa-bully-harvey-weinstein-ratings-308359 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=5 April 2012 |accessdate=2 April 2013}} He traveled to China in 2011 in an effort to encourage the Chinese government to both crack down on piracy and further open its film market.{{cite news |title=MPAA's Chris Dodd Presses China to Open Film Market |author=Jonathan Landreth |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/mpaas-chris-dodd-presses-china-200784 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=2 April 2013}} A settlement of a long-argued [[World Trade Organization]] complaint, coupled with Dodd's efforts, contributed to the United States' agreement with China in 2012 to open China's film market to more Hollywood films and to increase U.S. studios' share of box office revenues in China.{{cite news|last1=Faughnder|first1=Ryan|title=Shake-up at the MPAA. Hollywood's chief lobbyist, Chris Dodd, to be replaced by Charles Rivkin|url=http://beta.latimes.com/business/hollywood/la-fi-ct-dodd-mpaa-exit-20170428-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|date=28 April 2017}} In addition to this agreement with China, the U.S. signed more than 20 memos of understanding with foreign governments regarding the enforcement of intellectual property rights during Dodd's tenure at the MPAA.{{cite news|last1=Petski|first1=Denise|title=Chris Dodd Stepping Down As Chairman Of MPAA; Charles Rivkin To Take Over|url=http://deadline.com/2017/04/chris-dodd-stepping-down-chairman-of-mpaa-motion-picture-association-of-america-1202079427/|work=Deadline|date=28 April 2017}} In 2011, the MPAA supported the passage of the [[Stop Online Piracy Act]] (SOPA) and [[PROTECT IP Act]] (PIPA).{{cite news |title=MPAA Chairman Chris Dodd Speaks Out Against 'Blackout' Protest of SOPA and PIPA |author=Alex Ben Block |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/mpaa-chris-dodd-blackout-piracy-sopa-282755 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=17 January 2012 |accessdate=2 April 2013}} After the two bills were shelved in early 2012, Dodd indicated that Hollywood might cut off campaign contributions to politicians who failed to support anti-piracy efforts in the future.{{cite news|title=Chris Dodd warns of Hollywood backlash against Obama over anti-piracy bill|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2012/01/19/exclusive-hollywood-lobbyist-threatens-to-cut-off-obama-2012-money-over-anti.html|work=Fox News|date=19 January 2012}} In 2012, the MPAA launched the Diversity and Multicultural Outreach program, as part of an effort to increase diversity in the television and film industry both through employment and representation on screen.{{cite web|title=Inclusion & Multicultural Outreach|url=https://www.mpaa.org/inclusion-multicultural-outreach/#outreach|publisher=Motion Picture Association of America|accessdate=16 February 2018}} Since its inception, the Diversity and Multicultural and Outreach group has conducted outreach and partnered with more than 20 multicultural groups and national civil rights organizations in sponsoring film screenings, festivals, and other diversity-themed events.{{cite news|last1=Garcia|first1=Tonya|title=MPAA Partners With "Dope" For American Black Film Festival Opening Night|url=http://madamenoire.com/537798/mpaa-dope-american-black-film-festival-opening-night/|work=MadameNoire|date=3 June 2015}} Throughout his tenure at the MPAA, Dodd also highlighted the need for movie studios to embrace technology as a means of distributing content.{{cite news |title=Chris Dodd Pushes Back Against Hollywood Vs. Technology Criticisms In SMPTE |author=Alex Ben Block |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/chris-dodd-mpaa-technology-smpte-253753 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=26 October 2011 |accessdate=2 April 2013}} In June 2017, the MPAA supported the launch of the Alliance for Creativity and Entertainment (ACE), a coalition of entertainment companies, including the six major studios, [[Netflix]] and [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]], that will draw on the MPAA's resources in an effort to reduce online piracy through research and legal efforts.{{cite news|last1=Lieberman|first1=David|title=Hollywood And Digital Companies Forge Global Anti-Piracy Alliance|url=http://deadline.com/2017/06/hollywood-digital-companies-forge-global-antipiracy-alliance-1202112346/|work=Deadline|date=13 June 2017}} As announced on April 28, 2017, former U.S. Ambassador to France and Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs Charles Rivkin succeeded Chris Dodd as CEO of the Motion Picture Association of America, effective September 5, 2017, and as chairman, effective December 6, 2017. ==Film rating system== {{Main|Motion Picture Association of America film rating system}} In 1968, the MPAA established the Code and Rating Administration, or CARA (later renamed the Classification and Rating Administration), which began issuing ratings for films exhibited and distributed commercially in the United States to help parents determine what films are appropriate for their children. Since the [[motion picture rating system|rating system]] was first introduced in November 1968, it has gone through several changes, including the addition of a PG-13 rating.{{cite news |title=Film Classification Starts Nov. 1 |author=Richard L. Coe |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ujwxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ogEEAAAAIBAJ&dq=mpaa%20film%20ratings%20system&pg=7248%2C5548739 |work=Toledo Blade |date=14 October 1968 |accessdate=12 March 2013}}{{cite news |title=Film Ratings Plan Will Be Revised |author=Charles Champlin |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WAscAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tloEAAAAIBAJ&dq=mpaa%20film%20ratings%20system&pg=6981%2C4372645 |work=The Victoria Advocate |date=29 January 1970 |accessdate=12 March 2013}} The ratings system is completely voluntary, and ratings have no legal standing.{{cite news |title=At last, an adult decision |author=Hal Lipper |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=3SKP-CMT0-0060-215N&csi=11063&oc=00240&perma=true |work=St. Petersburg Times |date=29 September 2009 |accessdate=1 May 2013}}{{cite news |title=Law limits some violent video games |author=Dan Richman |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/news/article/Law-limits-some-violent-video-games-1115175.php |work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer |date=20 May 2003 |accessdate=10 May 2013}} Instead, theater owners enforce the MPAA film ratings after they have been assigned,{{cite news |title=CinemaCon: MPAA Tweaks Movie Ratings System in Wake of Newtown School Shooting |author=Pamela McClintock |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cinemacon-mpaa-tweaks-movie-ratings-440392 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=16 March 2013 |accessdate=10 May 2013}} with many theaters refusing to exhibit non-rated films.{{cite news |title=Weinstein Co. to Release Unrated 'Bully' in Protest of 'R' |author=Pamela McClintock |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/weinstein-bully-unrated-rated-r-mpaa-304232 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=26 March 2012 |accessdate=9 May 2013}} An unrated film is often denoted by "NR", such as in newspapers, although this is not a formal MPAA rating.{{cite book |first=Daniel P. |last=Franklin |title=Politics and Film: The Political Culture of Film in the United States |year=2006 |publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]] |isbn=9781461641018 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=eQp4AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA153 153]}} In 2006 the film ''[[This Film Is Not Yet Rated]]'' alleged that the MPAA gave preferential treatment to member studios during the process of assigning ratings,{{cite news |title=''This Film Is Not Yet Rated'' |author=Peter Travers |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/this-film-is-not-yet-rated-20060803 |work=Rolling Stone |date=3 August 2006 |accessdate=28 May 2013}} as well as criticizing the rating process for its lack of transparency. In response, the MPAA posted its ratings rules, policies, and procedures, as well as its appeals process, online.{{cite news |title=MPAA, NATO reform ratings system |author=Pamela McClintock |url=https://variety.com/2007/film/news/mpaa-nato-reform-ratings-system-1117957535/ |work=Variety |date=16 January 2007 |accessdate=7 May 2013}} According to a 2015 study commissioned by CARA, ninety-three percent of parents in the U.S. find the rating system to be a helpful tool.{{cite news|last1=McClintock|first1=Pamela|title=Movie Ratings: Sex Remains Top Concern for American Parents, Not Violence|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/movie-ratings-sex-remains-top-845507|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=3 December 2015}} The ratings currently used by the MPAA's voluntary system are:{{cite web |url= http://www.mpaa.org/film-ratings/ |title=Film Ratings |work=MPAA.org |accessdate=4 August 2014}} {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |- ! Rating !! Meaning !! MPAA's Explanation |- | align="center" | '''G''' || General Audiences || "Nothing that would offend parents for viewing by children." On the box: "All ages admitted" |- | align="center" | '''PG''' || Parental Guidance Suggested || "Parents urged to give 'parental guidance.' May contain some material parents might not like for their young children." On the box: "Some material may not be suitable for children" |- | align="center" | '''PG-13''' || Parents Strongly Cautioned || "Parents are urged to be cautious. Some material may be inappropriate for pre-teenagers." On the box: "Some material may be inappropriate for children under 13" |- | align="center" | '''R''' || Restricted || "Contains some adult material. Parents are urged to learn more about the film before taking their young children with them." On the box: "Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian" |- | align="center" | '''NC-17'''|| Adults Only || "Clearly adult. Children are not admitted." On the box: "No One 17 and Under Admitted" |} ==Members== The original members of the MPAA were the "Big Eight" film studios, [[Paramount Pictures]], [[20th Century Fox]], [[Loews Cineplex Entertainment|Loews]], [[Universal Pictures|Universal Studios]], [[Warner Bros.]], [[Columbia Pictures]], [[United Artists]], and [[RKO Pictures]].{{cite book |last=Spring |first=Joel |title=Images of American Life |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kvWRWJrRePAC&pg=PA50&dq=founding+member+mppda&hl=en&sa=X&ei=o3o5UYvSNKbI2wWrkYCgCA&ved=0CGIQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=founding%20member%20mppda&f=false |accessdate=7 March 2013 |year=1992 |publisher=State University of New York Press |location=Albany |isbn=0791410706 |page=50 }} Two years later, Loews merged with [[Metro Pictures]], [[Goldwyn Pictures]], and [[Louis B. Mayer|Louis B. Mayer Productions]] to form [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]].{{cite book |title=Movers and Shakers: The 100 Most Influential Figures in Modern Business |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GPdNo2nVAFAC&pg=PA253&dq=metro+goldwyn+mayer+merger+form+mgm&hl=en&sa=X&ei=No9DUb-rOJKA2AWw2oCoCQ&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=metro%20goldwyn%20mayer%20merger%20form%20mgm&f=false |accessdate=14 March 2013 |year=2003 |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing Plc |isbn=0738209147 |page=253 }} [[United Artists]] briefly resigned from the organization in 1956 over a ratings dispute, although they rejoined later in the decade.{{cite web |url=http://www.afi.com/members/catalog/DetailView.aspx?s=&Movie=51583 |title=The Man with the Golden Arm |work=American Film Institute |accessdate=19 March 2013}} By 1966, [[Monogram Pictures|Allied Artists Pictures]] had joined the original members.{{cite book |last=Vaughn |first=Stephen |title=Freedom and Entertainment: Rating the Movies in an Age of New Media |url=http://www.suu.edu/faculty/petersent/pdf/mpaaresearch.pdf |accessdate=7 March 2013 |year=2006 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=New York |isbn=0521676541 |page=23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712230400/http://www.suu.edu/faculty/petersent/pdf/mpaaresearch.pdf |archivedate=12 July 2014 |df= }} In the following decade, new members joining the MPAA included [[Embassy Pictures|Avco Embassy]] in 1975 and [[Walt Disney Studios (division)|Walt Disney Studios]] in 1979.{{cite news |first=A H |last=Weiler |title=Jack Valenti, pres of Motion Picture Assn of Amer... |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=3SJB-2MX0-0028-93DM&csi=6745&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=New York Times |date=26 January 1975 |accessdate=5 March 2013}}{{cite news |first=Gary |last=Arnold |title=Film Notes |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=3S8G-BVX0-0009-W484&csi=8075&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=Washington Post |date=5 April 1980 |accessdate=5 March 2013}}{{cite news |title=Movie Group's Meeting At Cannes Is Canceled |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=3S8G-BFN0-0007-H3F3&csi=6742&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=New York Times |date=29 April 1986 |accessdate=5 March 2013}} The next year, [[Filmways]] became a MPAA member, but was later replaced in 1986 along with Avco Embassy when the [[De Laurentiis Entertainment Group]] and [[Orion Pictures]] joined the MPAA roster. In 1995 the MPAA members were: the Walt Disney Studios; Paramount Pictures; Universal Studios; Warner Bros; 20th Century Fox; MGM—which included United Artists after their 1981 merger—and [[Sony Pictures]], which included Columbia and [[TriStar Pictures]] after their acquisition in 1989.{{cite book |last=Cook |first=David |title=Lost Illusions: American Cinema in the Shadow of Wtergate and Vietnam |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HVygqYMVP2wC&q=mgm+united+artist#v=snippet&q=mgm%20united%20artist&f=false |accessdate=7 March 2013 |year=2000 |publisher=University of California Press |location=Berkeley |isbn=0520232658 |page=21}}{{cite news|title=Sony to Buy Columbia, Says Americans Will Run Studio : 1st Sale of Film Maker to Japanese |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-09-27/news/mn-335_1_columbia-pictures-entertainment|accessdate=24 September 2012 |newspaper=latimes.com |date=27 September 1989}} [[Turner Entertainment]] joined the MPAA in 1995, but was purchased in 1996 by [[Time Warner]].{{cite news |first=Dennis |last=Wharton |title=Turner Pix Joins MPAA |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=3S3M-F440-0006-000R&csi=140595&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=Daily Variety |date=25 January 1995 |accessdate=5 March 2013}}{{cite news |first=Geraldine |last=Fabrikant |title=Holders Back Time Warner-Turner Merger |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/business/holders-back-time-warner-turner-merger.html |newspaper=New York Times |date=11 October 1996 |accessdate=14 March 2013}} As of 2017 the MPAA member companies are: Walt Disney Studios; Paramount Pictures Corporation; Sony Pictures Entertainment Inc.; Twentieth Century Fox; Universal Studios LLC; and Warner Bros Entertainment Inc.{{cite web |title=Who We Are – Our Story |publisher=Motion Picture Association of America |url=http://www.mpaa.org/our-story/ |accessdate=April 27, 2017}} ==Content protection efforts== The MPAA's concerted efforts at fighting [[copyright infringement]] began in 1975 with the establishment of the Film Security Office, which sought to recover unauthorized recordings of films in order to prevent duplication. The MPAA has continued to pursue a number of initiatives to combat illegal distribution of films and TV shows, especially in response to new technologies. In the 1980s, it spoke out against [[Videocassette recorder|VCRs]] and the threat that the MPAA believed they represented to the movie industry,{{cite news |title=Putting the Bite On the Home VCR |author=William D. Marbach |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=3SJ4-FRJ0-0008-X3VM&csi=5774&oc=00240&perma=true |work=Newsweek |date=26 April 1982 |accessdate=6 March 2013}} with MPAA president [[Jack Valenti]] drawing a parallel between the threat of the VCR and that of the [[Boston Strangler]].{{cite news |title=The invasion of the VCRs |author=Malcolm Jones |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=3SKP-90V0-0060-2035&csi=11063&oc=00240&perma=true |work=St. Petersburg Times |date=26 April 1987 |accessdate=6 March 2013}} In 1986, the MPAA asked Congress to pass a law that would require VCRs to come equipped with a chip to prevent them from making copies. Legal efforts at stopping homemade copies of broadcast television largely ended, however, when the [[United States Supreme Court]] ruled that such copying constituted [[fair use]].{{cite news |title='Distortion' Charged; DAT Anticopy Technology Debated At Joint Hill Hearing |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=3TVV-HHR0-0019-30PX&csi=6944&oc=00240&perma=true |work=Communications Daily |date=3 April 1987 |accessdate=6 March 2013}} The MPAA continued to support law enforcement efforts to stop [[bootleg recording|bootleg]] production and distribution of videos tapes and [[laserdisc]]s into the 1990s,{{cite news |title=Picture This |author=Seth Goldstein |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TAgEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=RA1-PA53&dq=MPAA%20laserdiscs&pg=RA1-PA53#v=onepage&q&f=false |work=Billboard |date=21 May 1994 |accessdate=19 March 2013}} and in 2000 took successful legal action against individuals posting [[DVD]] [[Digital rights management#DRM and film|decryption software]] on the Internet in [[Universal City Studios, Inc. v. Reimerdes]].{{cite news |title=Content de-scrambling fought |author=Sam Costella |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=414V-TG80-00J5-J3D9&csi=169977&oc=00240&perma=true |work=InfoWorld Daily News |date=6 September 2000 |accessdate=8 March 2013}} Following the release of [[RealDVD]]—an application that enabled users to make copies of DVDs—[[RealNetworks]] sued the [[DVD Copy Control Association]] and the major studios in 2008 over the legality of the software, accusing them of violating the [[Sherman Antitrust Act]].{{cite news |title=RealNetworks accuses MPAA of antitrust violations |author=Greg Sandoval |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1023_3-10240490-93.html |work=CNET |date=13 May 2009 |accessdate=28 May 2013}} The judgment found there were no grounds for the antitrust claim and dismissed [[RealNetworks, Inc. v. DVD Copy Control Association, Inc.|the suit]].{{cite news |title=Judge Slams MPAA 'Cartel' Allegations |author=David Kravets |url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2010/01/judge-slams-mpaa-cartel-allegations/ |work=Wired |date=11 January 2010 |accessdate=28 May 2013}} The court later found that the RealNetworks product violated the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA).{{cite news|last1=Goel|first1=Vindu|title=RealNetworks Drops Fight to Sell DVD Copying Software|url=https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/03/03/realnetworks-drops-fight-to-sell-dvd-copying-software/?mtrref=en.wikipedia.org&gwh=BE322A0601B9731550114F9E6090EACE&gwt=pay|work=The New York Times|date=3 March 2010}} The MPAA has continued to support law enforcement efforts to prevent illegal distribution of copyrighted materials online.{{cite news |title=MPAA Cheers Prison Sentence For Leader Of Internet Piracy Ring |author=David Lieberman |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/01/mpaa-imagine-group-justice-department-conviction-sentencing/ |work=Deadline.com |date=4 January 2013 |accessdate=22 April 2013}} The MPAA and its British counterpart, the [[Federation Against Copyright Theft]] (FACT), also funded the training of [[Lucky and Flo]], a pair of [[Labrador Retrievers]], to detect polycarbonates used in the manufacturing of DVDs.{{cite web |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/125679/article.html |title=MPAA Trains Dogs to Sniff Out Pirate DVDs |author=Jeremy Kirk |date=11 May 2006 |work=PCWorld |accessdate=5 March 2013}} ===Online file sharing=== In the early 2000s, the MPAA began focusing its efforts to curb copyright infringement specifically on [[peer-to-peer]] [[file sharing]], initially using a combination of educational campaigns{{cite news |title=Music piracy persists at Boston U., nationwide despite lawsuits |author=Dan Atkinson |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4B6F-HJW0-00K4-105J&csi=172244&oc=00240&perma=true |work=University Wire |date=10 December 2003 |accessdate=8 March 2013}} and [[cease and desist]] letters to discourage such activity. In the first six months of 2002, the MPAA sent more than 18,000 such letters to [[internet service provider]]s to forward to users engaged in copyright infringement.{{cite news |title=Shiver me timbers: Online bootlegs bane of entertainment industry |author=Simon Woolley |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4600-8XW0-015H-052Y&csi=244819&oc=00240&perma=true |work=Townsville Bulletin/Townsville Sun |date=3 June 2002 |accessdate=8 March 2013}} In late 2004, the MPAA changed course and filed lawsuits in a concerted effort to address copyright infringement on a number of large online file-sharing services, including [[BitTorrent]] and [[eDonkey network|eDonkey]].{{cite web |url=https://arstechnica.com/uncategorized/2004/12/4467-2/ |title=MPAA lawsuits target BitTorrent, eDonkey and Direct Connect networks |author=Fred Locklear |date=14 December 2004 |work=Ars Technica |accessdate=5 March 2013}} The following year, the MPAA expanded its legal actions to include lawsuits against individuals who downloaded and distributed copyrighted material via peer-to-peer networks.{{cite news |title=MPAA Anti-Piracy Lawsuits Target Individuals |author=Bary Alyssa Johnson |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4H0K-M4X0-01KX-14V2&csi=262320&oc=00240&perma=true |work=PC Magazine |date=29 August 2005 |accessdate=6 March 2013}} The MPAA also played a role in encouraging the [[Government of Sweden|Swedish government]] to conduct [[the Pirate Bay raid|a raid of the Pirate Bay]] file-sharing website in May 2006.{{cite web |url=http://www.slyck.com/story1227.html |title=Sweden Pressured to take Pirate Bay Action |author=Thomas Mennecke |date=20 June 2006 |work=Slyck.com |accessdate=5 March 2013}} Swedish officials have acknowledged that part of the motivation for the raid was the threat of sanctions from the [[World Trade Organization]], along with a letter from the MPAA.{{cite news |title=U.S. Joins Industry in Piracy War |author=Frank Ahrens |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/06/14/AR2006061402071.html |work=The Washington Post |date=15 June 2006 |accessdate=6 March 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.se/4128/20060621/#.UTdo1nyY4RE |title=US threatened Sweden with sanctions over piracy |author=Adam Ewing |date=21 June 2006 |work=The Local |accessdate=6 March 2013}} In 2013 the [[Center for Copyright Information]] unveiled the [[Copyright Alert System]], a system established through an agreement between the MPAA, the [[Recording Industry Association of America]], and five of the USA's largest [[internet service providers]].{{cite news |title=MPAA-Backed Copyright Alert System Unveiled |author=Sean J. Miller |url=http://www.backstage.com/news/mpaa-backed-copyright-alert-system-unveiled/ |work=Back Stage |date=26 February 2013 |accessdate=22 April 2013}} The system used a third-party service to identify content being distributed illegally. Users were then informed that their accounts were being used for possible copyright infringement and were provided with information about ways to get authorized content online.{{cite news |title=The new copyright alert system is running |author=Sarah Laskow |url=http://www.cjr.org/cloud_control/cas_system_already_in_action.php?page=all |work=Columbia Journalism Review |date=28 February 2013 |accessdate=22 April 2013}} Users who received multiple notices of infringement faced "mitigations measures," such as temporary slowing of their Internet service, but the system did not include termination of subscriber accounts. Subscribers facing such action had a right to appeal to the [[American Arbitration Association]].{{cite web |url=http://www.copyrightinformation.org/resources-faq/copyright-alert-system-faqs/ |title=Copyright Alert System FAQs |work=copyrightinformation.org |publisher=Center for Copyright Information |accessdate=25 April 2013}} In January 2017, the Copyright Alert System was discontinued. While no official reason was given, the MPAA's general counsel stated that the system had not been equipped to stop repeat infringers.{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Ted|title=Internet Service Providers, Studios and Record Labels Call It Quits on Copyright Alert System|url=https://variety.com/2017/digital/news/copyright-alerts-piracy-mpaa-comcast-att-1201971756/|work=Variety|date=27 January 2017}} On December 24, 2014, the [[Sony Pictures hack]] revealed that following a lawsuit in which the MPAA won a multimillion judgment against [[Hotfile]], a file hosting website, the MPAA colluded with Hotfile to misrepresent the settlement so that the case would serve as a deterrent. The settlement was previously believed to be $80 million and was widely reported; however, Hotfile only paid the studios $4 million and agreed to have the $80 million figure recorded as the judgment and the website shut down.{{cite news|last1=Van der Sar|first1=Ernesto|title=MPAA Secretly Settled With Hotfile for $4 Million, Not $80 Million|url=https://torrentfreak.com/mpaa-secretly-settled-hotfile-4-million-80-million-141224/|work=Torrentfreak|date=24 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.neowin.net/news/sony-email-leak-has-uncovered-the-truth-behind-mpaa-and-hotfile-dispute|title=Sony email leak has uncovered the truth behind MPAA and Hotfile dispute|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20141224/06321429517/sony-hack-reveals-that-mpaas-big-80-million-settlement-with-hotfile-was-lie.shtml|title=Sony Hack Reveals That MPAA's Big '$80 Million' Settlement With Hotfile Was A Lie|publisher=}} In a case resolved in 2015, the MPAA and others supported the [[United States International Trade Commission]] (ITC)'s decision to consider electronic transmissions to the U.S. as "articles" so that it could prevent the importation of digital files of counterfeit goods. While the case being considered by the ITC involved dental appliances, the ITC could have also used such authority to bar the importation of pirated movies and TV shows from rogue foreign websites that traffic in infringing content.{{cite news|last1=Gardner|first1=Eriq|title=With the MPAA Watching, ITC Says Case About Teeth Won't Bring Down the Internet|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/mpaa-watching-itc-says-case-775397|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=19 February 2015}} The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals took up the matter, and ultimately ruled against the ITC.{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Ted|title=MPAA Warns Appellate Ruling Could Limit Ability to Fight Digital Piracy|url=https://variety.com/2015/biz/news/mpaa-digital-goods-piracy-google-1201637501/|work=Variety|date=10 November 2015}} In 2016, the MPAA reported [[Putlocker]] as one of the "top 5 rogue cyberlocker services" to the [[Office of the United States Trade Representative]] as a major piracy threat; the website was then blocked in the United Kingdom.{{cite news |last=Sandoval |first=Greg |date=31 March 2012 |title=MPAA wants more criminal cases brought against 'rogue' sites |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/mpaa-wants-more-criminal-cases-brought-against-rogue-sites/ |publisher=[[CNET]] |access-date=17 October 2016 }}{{cite news |last=Prabhu |first=Vijay |date=17 October 2016 |title=Yet Another Video Streaming Service Bites The Dust, Putlocker Shuts Down |url=http://www.techworm.net/2016/10/putlocker-video-streaming-service-shuts.html |publisher=TechWorm |access-date=17 October 2016 }}{{cite news |last=Bolton |first=Doug |date=26 May 2016 |title=Putlocker blocked in the UK by internet service providers after High Court order |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/putlocker-blocked-down-virgin-media-sky-internet-streaming-watch-online-videos-a7050056.html |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |access-date=17 October 2016 }} ==Criticism and controversies== ===Publicity campaigns=== The MPAA has also produced publicity campaigns to discourage piracy. The ''[[Who Makes Movies?]]'' advertising campaign in 2003 highlighted workers in the movie industry describing how piracy affected them. The video spots ran as trailers before movies, and as television advertisements.{{cite news |title=H'wood steps up antipiracy fight |author=Brooks Boliek |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4BG8-SXP0-01V4-X35T&csi=12015&oc=00240&perma=true |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=23 July 2003 |accessdate=5 March 2013}} In 2004, the MPAA began using the slogan "[[You can click, but you can't hide]]". This slogan appeared in messages that replaced file-sharing websites after they had been shut down through MPAA legal action.{{cite news |title=Movie body hits peer-to-peer nets |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/4256449.stm |work=BBC News |date=11 February 2005 |accessdate=5 March 2013}} It also appeared in posters and videos distributed to video stores by the MPAA.{{cite news |title=MPAA Files Piracy Suits |author=Greg Hernandez |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4DTP-V1K0-TWDH-T3C9&csi=157105&oc=00240&perma=true |work=The Daily News of Los Angeles |date=17 November 2004 |accessdate=5 March 2013}} Also in 2004, the MPAA partnered with the [[Intellectual Property Office of Singapore]] to release [[You Wouldn't Steal a Car|a trailer shown before films in theaters equating piracy with theft]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ipos.gov.sg/main/newsroom/media_rel/mediarelease1_270704.html |title=Be HIP at the Movies |author= |date=27 July 2004 |work=Intellectual Property Office of Singapore |accessdate=6 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924044120/http://www1.ipos.gov.sg/main/newsroom/media_rel/mediarelease1_270704.html |archivedate=September 24, 2008 }} The trailer was later placed at the beginning of the video on many DVDs in such a way that it could not be bypassed (not being able to skip or fast-forward), which triggered criticism and a number of parodies.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/8106805.stm |title=Getting inside a downloader's head |author=Finlo Rohrer |date=18 June 2009 |work=BBC |accessdate=6 March 2013}} In 2005 the MPAA commissioned a study to examine the effects of file sharing on movie industry profitability. The study concluded that the industry lost $6.1 billion per year to piracy, and that up to 44 percent of domestic losses were due to file sharing by college students. In 2008, the MPAA revised the percentage of loss due to college students down to 15 percent, citing human error in the initial calculations of this figure. Beyond the percentage of the loss that was attributable to college students, however, no other errors were found in the study.{{cite news|title=MPAA admits mistake on downloading study |author=Justin Pope |url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/98009/page/1 |work=Newsweek |date=23 January 2008 |accessdate=5 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080207045516/http://www.newsweek.com/id/98009/page/1 |archivedate=February 7, 2008 }} In 2015, theaters began airing the MPAA's "I Make Movies" series, an ad campaign intended to combat piracy by highlighting the stories of behind-the-scenes employees in the film and television industry.{{cite news|last1=Sneider|first1=Jeff|title=MPAA to Run 'I Make Movies' Ads at AMC Theaters, Local Cinema Chains|url=https://www.thewrap.com/mpaa-to-run-i-make-movies-ads-at-amc-theaters-local-cinema-chains/|work=The Wrap|date=25 June 2015}} The series pointed audiences to the MPAA's "WhereToWatch" website (later dubbed "The Credits"){{cite web|url=https://www.thecredits.org/|website=mpaa.org|title=The Credits|accessdate=16 February 2018}} which provides attention to the behind-the-scenes creativity involved in making movies. ===Accusations of copyright infringement=== The MPAA itself has been accused of copyright infringement on multiple occasions. In 2007, the creator of a [[Blog software|blogging platform]] called Forest Blog accused the MPAA of violating the license for the platform, which required that users link back to the Forest Blog website. The MPAA had used the platform for its own blog, but without linking back to the Forest Blog website. The MPAA subsequently took the blog offline, and explained that the software had been used on a test basis and the blog had never been publicized.{{cite news|title=MPAA: We Were Only Testing Forest Blog|url=https://torrentfreak.com/mpaa-we-were-only-testing-forest-blog|work=Torrentfreak|date=28 February 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bit-tech.net/news/bits/2007/02/19/MPAA_violates_software_license/ |title=MPAA violates software license |author=Brett Thomas |date=19 February 2007 |work=bit-tech.net |accessdate=5 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110183631/http://www.bit-tech.net/news/bits/2007/02/19/MPAA_violates_software_license/ |archivedate=November 10, 2013 }} Also in 2007, the MPAA released a software toolkit for universities to help identify cases of file sharing on campus. The software used parts of the [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] [[Linux]] distribution, released under the [[GNU General Public License|General Public License]], which stipulates that the source code of any projects using the distribution be made available to third parties. The source code for the MPAA's toolkit, however, was not made available. When the MPAA was made aware of the violation, the software toolkit was removed from their website.{{cite news |title=MPAA's University Toolkit hit with DMCA takedown notice after GPL violation |author=Ryan Paul |url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2007/12/mpaas-university-toolkit-hit-with-dmca-takedown-notice-after-gpl-violation/ |work=Ars Technica |date=4 December 2007 |accessdate=5 March 2013}} In 2006, the MPAA admitted having made illegal copies of ''[[This Film Is Not Yet Rated]]'' (a documentary exploring the MPAA itself and the history of its [[MPAA film rating system|rating system]])[https://web.archive.org/web/20060130093854/http://www.latimes.com/business/custom/cotown/cl-et-mpaa24jan24,0,2188275.story MPAA finds itself accused of piracy], by John Horn; at the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' (via [[archive.org]]); published January 24, 2006; retrieved June 11, 2014 — an act which ''[[Ars Technica]]'' explicitly described as [[hypocrisy]][https://arstechnica.com/uncategorized/2006/01/6036-2/ MPAA admits to unauthorized movie copying], by Eric Bangeman, at ''[[Ars Technica]]''; published January 24, 2006; retrieved June 11, 2014 and which [[Roger Ebert]] called "rich irony".[http://www.rogerebert.com/festivals-and-awards/sundance-7-film-ratings-exposed Sundance #7: Film ratings exposed!], by [[Roger Ebert]]; at [[RogerEbert.com]]; published January 26, 2006; retrieved June 11, 2014 The MPAA subsequently claimed that it had the legal right to copy the film despite this being counter to the filmmaker's explicit request, because the documentary's exploration of the MPAA's ratings board was potentially a violation of the board members' privacy. ==See also== {{Portal|Film|United States}} * [[Australian Classification Board]] * [[British Board of Film Classification]] * [[DeCSS]]: decryption program for DVD video discs using [[Content Scramble System]] * [[Entertainment Software Rating Board]] * [[National Association of Theatre Owners]] * [[Notorious markets]] * [[Operation Red Card]] * [[Pre-Code Hollywood]] * [[You Wouldn't Steal a Car]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website}} * [http://mppda.flinders.edu.au MPPDA Digital Archives (1922–1939)] * [http://catalog.oscars.org/vwebv/holdingsInfo?bibId=66279 Motion Picture Association of America. revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file = Lorenzo Lotto 036.jpg | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 320px | title = Mystic Marriage of St Catherine and Saints | artist = [[Lorenzo Lotto]] | year = 1524 | medium = Oil on panel | height_metric = 115 | width_metric = 98 | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | museum = Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica | city = [[Rome]] }} '''''Mystical Marriage of St Catherine and Saints''''' is an [[oil painting]] by [[Lorenzo Lotto]], signed, now in the Collections of the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica ([[Palazzo Barberini]]), [[Rome]], [[Italy]].
==Description== The work was commissioned by the merchant Felice Cassotti from Lotto while the latter was working in Bergamo. The painting hung in the nuptial bedroom of Cassotti's son. The work is signed on the Madonna's throne. The painting once hung in the [[Palazzo Quirinale]].
Lotto in 1523 had painted a portrait of the married couple, Marsilio Cassotti and Faustina Assonica, a work now on display in the [[Prado Museum]]. In this depiction of the [[Mystical marriage of Saint Catherine|mystical marriage of Saint Catherine of Alexandria]], the saint kneeling accepts from the child Jesus a rose, the latter symbol of love and martyrdom; in her left hand is a marital ring. Hanging from a sash is a purse with the name of Christ; the sash has a medallion with an angel holding a balance. Around these figures are St Jerome paging his bible, with lion at the feet (left lower corner); St George dressed as a knight with his lance (left upper corner); beside him hovering behind the Virgin is St Sebastian with an arrow; Saint Nicholas of Myra with a bishop's crozier with three gold spheres, conversing with St Anthony Abbot with bells (right upper corner).<ref>[http://galleriabarberini.beniculturali.it/index.php?it/103/lotto-sposalizio-mistico-di-santa-caterina-e-santi Galleria Barberini], entry on painting.</ref> Like many other Lotto paintings, the figures seem engaged in movement.

{{Infobox artwork | title = Praetorians Relief | image_file = Lens - Inauguration du Louvre-Lens le 4 décembre 2012, la Galerie du Temps, n° 058.JPG | image_size = 300px | other_language_1 = French | other_title_1 = | type = [[Relief#High relief|High relief]], [[bas-relief]] | artist = unknown | year = {{circa|51–52}} | material = Grey veined [[marble]] | height_metric = 160 | width_metric = 122 | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | condition = Extant | accession = LL.398 | city = | museum = [[Louvre-Lens]], France | coordinates = | url = }}
The '''Praetorians Relief''' is a [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] marble relief dated to {{circa|51–52}} AD and housed in the [[Louvre-Lens]].<ref name="afa">{{cite web | url =http://www.afaweb.org/exhibitions/details/documents/HighlightsofRomanArtfromtheLouvre.pdf| title =Highlights of Roman art from the Louvre|publisher =[[American Federation of Arts]]| page=3|accessdate =23 Aug 2014}}</ref>
It depicts three soldiers in [[Relief#High relief|high relief]] in the foreground, while two others in the background, accompanied by a standard bearer, are made in [[bas-relief]]. The standard-bearer holds an [[Aquila (Roman)|aquila standard]], where the eagle grasps a thunderbolt in its talons. The soldiers have been identified as [[Praetorians]] due to the richness of the apparel, particularly the helmets, the ceremonial dress and oval shields.<ref>{{cite book | author =Lawrence Keppie | title =The Making of the Roman Army: From Republic to Empire| publisher =University of Oklahoma Press | year =1998 | pages =233–234 | isbn =0806130148}}</ref> The figures are wearing [[calcei]] and not [[caligae]], worn by ordinary soldiers. However, according to [[Boris Rankov]], "the [[Attic helmet|Attic-style helmets]] are almost certainly an artistic convention".<ref name="Rankov">{{cite book | author =Boris Rankov | title =The Praetorian Guard| publisher =Osprey Publishing | year =1994 | page =20 | isbn =1855323613}}</ref> Rankov suggests that "early in their history the Praetorians were still using the [[Montefortino helmet|Montefortino-style helmet]] normal in the [[Roman legion|legions]] of the [[Roman Republic|Republic]] and early [[Roman Empire|Empire]]".<ref name="Rankov"/>
The relief was previously dated to the early 2nd century AD. The lower half of the left-hand figure, portions of the middle two and the heads of all three foreground figures are modern restorations. In 2006 the relief underwent restoration by N. Imbert and A. Méthivier.<ref name="Ancientrome">{{cite web | url =http://ancientrome.ru/art/artwork/img.htm?id=2537| script-title=ru:Рельеф с преторианцами |publisher =Ancientrome.ru| language=Russian|accessdate =23 Aug 2014}}</ref>
==Provenance== The Praetorians Relief was once part of the [[Arch of Claudius (British victory)|Arch of Claudius]], erected in 51 to commemorate the [[Roman conquest of Britain|conquest of Britain]].<ref name="afa"/> The relief is mentioned already in the 16th century. The head of the standard-bearer is depicted in ''Album'' by [[Pierre Jacques de Reims]], on the page dated to 1577.<ref name="Ancientrome"/> The relief was once in the possession of the [[Mattei family]], in 1824 it was purchased by the French.
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Refimprove|date=March 2015}} [[File:Firmas de Rembrandt.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Signatures by Rembrandt published by the Rembrandt Research Project.]] The '''Rembrandt Research Project''' (RRP) is an initiative of the [[Nederlandse Organisatie voor Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek]] (NWO), which is the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research. Its purpose is to organize and categorize research on [[Rembrandt]], with the aim of discovering new facts about this [[Dutch Golden Age]] painter and his studio. The project was started in 1968, but has since become the authority on Rembrandt and has final say in whether a painting is ''genuine''.
==Results== As a result of the project, which analyzed documentation, techniques, and forensic research on Rembrandt paintings from his early years in [[Leiden]] until his death, the number of signed Rembrandt ''self-portraits'' around the world has been reduced by half. Also, more paintings have been attributed to [[List of Rembrandt pupils|students working in the Rembrandt studio]], and more has been discovered about the ways in which the students worked. Recently, period copies of Rembrandt paintings are being studied for clues as to whether certain copies were factory-style pieces for visiting functionaries. Rembrandt's work was in high demand for decades, and he managed to keep productivity up while also keeping his prices high by enforcing strict quality control on the work done in his studio.
The project's six-volume publication, ''A Corpus of Rembrandt Paintings'', is considered the definitive authority by all auction houses and dealers who work with works by Rembrandt and his studio. The research project has proved invaluable to art historians, and the lack of such a project for other prominent Dutch painters such as [[Frans Hals]] is felt sorely by museums and collectors trying to acquire the same sort of ''stamp of approval'' on their paintings. However, the project has also initiated debate about the feasibility of conclusive attribution, particularly for painters who were associated with one or more workshops.
=== Publications === * ''A Corpus of Rembrandt Paintings'', various writers, in six volumes:<ref>[https://www.springer.com/series/6494 Springer Verlag: Rembrandt Reserarch Project Foundation]</ref> :: Volume I, ''1629-1631'', 1982 (over early years in Leiden) :: Volume II, ''1621-1634'', 1986 :: Volume III, ''1635-1642'', 1989 :: Volume IV, E. van de Wetering (editor), ''Self-Portraits'', 2005 :: Volume V, E. van de Wetering (editor), ''The Small-Scale History Paintings'', 2010 :: Volume VI, E. van de Wetering (editor), ''Rembrandt’s Paintings Revisited, A Complete Survey'', 2014 * Ernst van de Wetering, ''Rembrandt: The Painter at Work'', Amsterdam University Press, 2009, {{ISBN|978-90-8964033-8}}. * Ernst van de Wetering, Barbara de Lange, ''Rembrandt in Nieuw Licht'', Local World, Amsterdam, 2009, {{ISBN|978-90-811681-7-5}}.
==Concordance with other Rembrandt catalogs== The research project is also the single point of reference regarding concordance with other catalogs of the master's works, though most of these reference each other, as well. Below is a partial list of some commonly quoted catalogs: * ''Catalogue extracted from the Register L R. fol. 29 to 39 inclusive, of the Inventory of the Effects of Rembrandt Van Rhyn'', deposited in the Office of the Administration of Insolvent Estates at Amsterdam, 1656 (published in English by Smith, 1836) * ''Beredeneerde catalogus der werken van Rembrandt van Rhyn, en van zyne leerlingen en navolgers, herkomende uit het kabinet van wylen den heer C. Ploos van Amstel, J.Cz., welke in het openbaar zullen verkogt worden'' (Sale catalog of works sold from the collection of [[Cornelis Ploos van Amstel]] on Tuesday 31 July 1810), C. Josi, Amsterdam 1810 * ''A catalogue raisonné of the works of the most eminent Dutch, Flemish, and French painters : in which is included a short biographical notice of the artists, with a copious description of their principal pictures; a statement of the prices at which such pictures have been sold at public sales on the continent and in England; a reference to the galleries and private collections, in which a large portion are at present; and the names of the artists by whom they have been engraved; to which is added, a brief notice of the scholars & imitators of the great masters of the above schools'', Volume 7 on "Rembrandt van Rhyn", by [[John Smith (art historian)|Smith, John, dealer in pictures]], 1836 * ''Rembrandt'', 8 volumes, by [[Wilhelm von Bode]] with [[Cornelis Hofstede de Groot]], 1897–1905 * ''[[Rembrandt catalog raisonné, 1908|Rembrandt : des Meisters Gemälde in 643 Abbildungen]]'', by [[Wilhelm Reinhold Valentiner]] and [[Adolf Rosenberg]], 1908 * ''Beschreibendes kritisches Verzeichnis der Werke der hervorragendsten Holländischen Mahler des XVII. Jahrhunderts (1907-1928)'', Volume 6 ''Rembrandt'', by [[Hofstede de Groot]], 1914 * ''[[Rembrandt catalog raisonné, 1935|Rembrandt Paintings]]'', by [[Abraham Bredius]], 1935 * ''Rembrandt : Gemälde'', by [[Kurt Bauch]], 1966 * ''Rembrandt'', by [[Bob Haak (art historian)|Bob Haak]], 1968 * ''[[Rembrandt catalog raisonné, 1968|Rembrandt]]'', by [[Horst Gerson]], 1968 * ''Rembrandt : the complete edition of the paintings'', a reworking of the Bredius 1935 list by Gerson with explicitly rejected attributions and re-attributions, 1969 * ''L' opera pittorica completa di Rembrandt'', by Paolo Lecaldano, 1969 * ''[[Rembrandt catalog raisonné, 1986|Rembrandt]]'', by [[Christian Tümpel]], 1986 * ''Rembrandt : catalogo completo dei dipinti'', by Leonard J. Slatkes, 1992 * ''The Rembrandt Book'', by Gary Schwarz, 2006
===Old man with turban=== In 1998, the pAn Amsterdam art fair showed a Rembrandt for the first time that until then had been attributed to his pupil [[Jacques des Rousseaux]]. This painting was first cataloged in 1917 by [[Abraham Bredius]], who accepted it as a Rembrandt. Later [[Kurt Bauch]] rejected this based on a photograph and attributed it to [[Jan Lievens]] without ever having seen the painting. [[Werner Sumowski]] re-attributed the painting based on photographs to Rousseaux as a rebuttal to the arguments by art historians Bauch, [[Jakob Rosenberg]] and [[Horst Gerson]].<ref name=catalog>Catalog [http://www.pan.nl/DesktopDefault.aspx?tabid=58&lg=nl pAn Amsterdam] 1998, p.11-17</ref> The Rembrandt Research project seeks to avoid such arguments by making attributions based on historical and forensic evidence. The study of Rembrandt's oevre includes study of drawings and etchings as well as paintings by a wide range of artists who were Rembrandt's contemporaries. Analysis of his techniques includes the study of paints and panel wood he and his contemporaries used, while x-rays of paintings reveal whether a painting is a copy based on the amount of "discovery" drawing in the underlayer.
The pAn 1998 catalog contains an article by [[Ernst van de Wetering]] with foto's of other depictions of the same man by [[Jan Lievens]], [[Gerard Dou]], and Jacques Rousseau (thus the mis-attribution). The man has clearly the same face in all four portraits.
====Rembrandt's father==== According to Van de Wetering, this is the man often referred to as ''Rembrandt's father'', who was probably not his father, but a functionary in the [[Leiden Guild of St. Luke|Leiden painters' guild]] or male model.<ref name=catalog /> <gallery> File:Rembrand-oude man met tulband-rrp.jpg|''Old man with turban'', Rembrandt. File:Jan Lievens - Sultan Soliman.jpg|''Sultan Soliman'', Lievens. File:Jan Adriaensz van Staveren - man in tulband.jpg|Old man with turban, [[Jan Adriaensz Staveren]]. File:Man in an Oriental Costume - Isaac de Jouderville.jpg|''Man in an Oriental Costume'', [[Isaac de Jouderville]] </gallery> {{Commons category|Rembrandt's father}}
==End== In early 2011, the RRP board voted to terminate the project by the end of 2011 even though approximately one-quarter of Rembrandt's oeuvre has not yet been investigated. A major reason for this decision was the lack of scholars available to assume responsibilities from the RRP's chair, [[Ernst van de Wetering]], who has been involved with the project since 1968. Other reasons cited included lack of funding, as the [[Nederlandse Organisatie voor Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek|Netherlands Organisation for Scientific Research]] ceased funding the project in 1998. However, with funding from the [[Mellon Foundation]], the [[Netherlands Institute for Art History]] and the [[Mauritshuis]] have launched a pilot initiative called the [http://www.rembrandtdatabase.org/ Rembrandt Database] that will build off of and supplement research from the RRP.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Rembrandt-Research-Project-ended/23044# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2011-12-13 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926052740/http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Rembrandt-Research-Project-ended/23044# |archive-date=2011-09-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Ernst van de Wetering]], chair of the Rembrandt Research Project *[[Bob Haak (art historian)|Bob Haak]], founder of the Rembrandt Research Project *[[John Smith (art historian)|John Smith]], wrote the first [[catalog raisonné]] of Rembrandt paintings in 1836 *[[Hofstede de Groot]], wrote a comprehensive update of Smith's catalog in 1914 *[[Abraham Bredius]], wrote his [[Rembrandt catalog raisonné, 1935|first catalog]] of Rembrandt paintings in 1935 *[[Horst Gerson]], first wrote [[Rembrandt catalog raisonné, 1968|his own catalog]] in 1968, followed by the first revision of Bredius's catalog in 1969 *[[Christian Tümpel]], wrote a [[Rembrandt catalog raisonné, 1986|comprehensive update]] of Gerson's catalog in 1986 *[[List of paintings by Rembrandt]], based on the 2014 (final?) list of the RRP published in "A Corpus of Rembrandt Paintings, Volume VI" *[[List of Rembrandt pupils]]
==References== {{reflist}}
===Bibliography=== * A Corpus of Rembrandt Paintings IV: The Self-Portraits (Rembrandt Research Project Foundation), Ernst van de Wetering, 2005
==External links== *[http://www.rembrandtresearchproject.org RRP website] with the latest additions to ''A Corpus of Rembrandt Paintings'' *[https://books.google.com/books?q=Ernst+van+de+Wetering&btnG=Boeken+zoeken Ernst van de Wetering in Google books]
{{Rembrandt}}
