{{italic title}} [[File:Berlioz- Roméo et Juliette - Handbill - Holoman p201.jpg|thumb|300px|Handbill advertising the first performance]] '''''Roméo et Juliette''''' is a ''symphonie dramatique,'' a large-scale [[choral symphony]] by French [[composer]] [[Hector Berlioz]], which was first performed on 24 November 1839. The [[libretto]] was written by [[Émile Deschamps]], and the completed work was assigned the catalogue numbers [[Opus number|Op.]] 17 and [[D. Kern Holoman|H.]] 79. It is based on [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare's]] play ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]''; it is regarded as one of Berlioz's finest works, and it is among the most original in form.{{cite book|author=[[Julian Rushton]]|url=http://www.cambridge.org/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521377676|title=Berlioz: Roméo et Juliette|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1994|series=Cambridge Music Handbooks}} The score is Berlioz's most comprehensive and detailed [[Program music|programmatic]] piece.[http://www.carringbush.net/~pml/music/berlioz/#h.79 CarringBush.net Berlioz page] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080605131207/http://www.carringbush.net/~pml/music/berlioz/ |date=2008-06-05 }} ==Composition== ===Genesis=== Initial inspiration came from a performance he witnessed in 1827 of ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' (in [[David Garrick]]'s edited version) at the [[Odéon|Odéon Theatre]] in Paris. The cast included [[Harriet Smithson]], who also inspired Berlioz's ''[[Symphonie fantastique]]''. In his ''Memoirs'', Berlioz describes the electrifying effect of the drama:
... to steep myself in the fiery sun and balmy nights of Italy, to witness the drama of that passion swift as thought, burning as lava, radiantly pure as an angel's glance, imperious, irresistible, the raging vendettas, the desperate kisses, the frantic strife of love and death, was more than I could bear. By the third act, scarcely able to breathe—it was as though an iron hand had gripped me by the heart—I knew that I was lost. I may add that at the time I did not know a word of English; I could only glimpse Shakespeare darkly through the mists of Letourneur's translation; the splendour of the poetry which gives a whole new glowing dimension to his glorious works was lost on me. ... But the power of the acting, especially that of Juliet herself, the rapid flow of the scenes, the play of expression and voice and gesture, told me more and gave me a far richer awareness of the ideas and passions of the original than the words of my pale and garbled translation could do.Berlioz; Cairns (2002), pp. 72–73.
The range of feeling and mood as well as poetic and formal invention which Berlioz found in Shakespeare{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/orchestras/philharmonic/learning/berlioz.shtml |title="Meet the Phil" – ''Romeo and Juliet'' – Berlioz" (6 April 2006). BBC Philharmonic website |accessdate=2007-08-17 |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226151953/http://www.bbc.co.uk/orchestras/philharmonic/learning/berlioz.shtml |archivedate=26 February 2008 |df= }} had a strong influence on his music, making a direct musical setting of Shakespeare's work only natural. In fact, he had been planning a musical realisation of ''Romeo and Juliet'' for a long time before 1838, but other projects intervened.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/proms/2007/aboutmusic/p23_berlioz.shtml BBC Proms | About the Music] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226152551/http://www.bbc.co.uk/proms/2007/aboutmusic/p23_berlioz.shtml |date=2008-02-26 }} Emile Deschamps (the [[libretto|librettist]] of the work) says that he and Berlioz worked out a plan for the symphony shortly after the Odéon's 1827/28 season. Indeed, it may be the case that ''Roméo et Juliette'''s genesis is intertwined with other works composed before the composer left for his [[Prix de Rome]] sojourn of 1830 to 1832. ''[[Prix de Rome Cantatas (Berlioz)|Sardanapale]]'', the cantata with which Berlioz finally won the Prix de Rome in 1830, includes the melodic material of both the ''Roméo seul'' ("Romeo alone") portion of the second movement and the ''Grande fête chez Capulet'' ("Great banquet at the Capulets").[http://hector.ucdavis.edu/Berlioz2003/ProgNotes/079R&Jnote.htm ''Roméo et Juliette'' programme notes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080114095707/http://hector.ucdavis.edu/Berlioz2003/ProgNotes/079R%26Jnote.htm |date=2008-01-14 }} Public domain: [http://hector.ucdavis.edu/Berlioz2003/ProgNotes/00NotesTP.html see here] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080114095702/http://hector.ucdavis.edu/Berlioz2003/ProgNotes/00NotesTP.html |date=2008-01-14 }} There is abundant evidence that Berlioz was gradually working out a scheme for ''Roméo et Juliette'' during his sojourn in Italy. He reviewed a February 1831 performance in [[Florence]] of [[Vincenzo Bellini|Bellini]]'s ''[[I Capuleti e i Montecchi]]'', outlining in passing how he would compose music for the ''Roméo et Juliette'' story: it would feature, he says, the sword fight, a concert of love, Mercutio's piquant buffooning, the terrible catastrophe, and the solemn oath of the two rival families. One line of text from the review eventually shows up in the libretto of the symphony. ===Realization=== The eventual composition of ''Roméo et Juliette'' as we know it now was made possible by the generous gift of 20,000 [[French franc|francs]] by [[Niccolò Paganini]]; after hearing a performance of ''[[Harold en Italie]]'' at the [[Conservatoire de Paris|Paris Conservatoire]] on 16 December 1838, the great [[virtuoso]] had publicly knelt before [[Hector Berlioz|Berlioz]] and hailed him as the heir of [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]]. Paganini died shortly after, and did not read or hear the piece. Berlioz used the money primarily to repay his debts, and afterwards was still left with "a handsome sum of money", which he used to allow himself to put his full focus towards working on "a really important work", unobstructed by his usual time-consuming obligations as a [[critic]].Berlioz; Cairns (2002), pp. 240–246. Berlioz finished the score on 8 September 1839.Cairns (1999), p. 192. The work's libretto is not sourced from the original plays, and as a result contains changes from Shakespeare's play, both in the version Berlioz worked from, and subsequent cuts he and his librettist made. Berlioz's composition was heavily influenced by the play he had seen acted by [[Charles Kemble]] and Harriet Smithson in 1827, which had been rewritten by the 18th century actor [[David Garrick]] to have Juliet awaken from her deathlike sleep before Romeo's death from (a much slower acting) poison. Berlioz enlisted the services of author Emile Deschamps to write the libretto. Between them they also left out the character of the nurse and expanded Shakespeare's brief mention of the two families' reconciliation into a substantial vocal finale. Berlioz developed a special predilection for the symphony over his career, writing in his memoirs that one movement in particular became a favorite: "If you now ask me which of my pieces I prefer, my answer will be that I share the view of most artists: I prefer the adagio (the Love Scene) in ''Romeo and Juliet''."Berlioz; Cairns (2002), p. 526. ==Performance== From composition until the first performance, [[Hector Berlioz|Berlioz]]'s time was occupied with physical arrangements for the premiere: parts were copied, chorus parts [[lithograph]]ed, and rehearsals got underway. The [[bass-baritone]], [[Adolphe-Louis Alizard]] (Friar Lawrence), and the ''Prologue'' [[choir|chorus]], all of whom came from the [[Paris Opéra]], were prepared during the intermissions of performances there. There was much anticipation in Paris prior to the first performance. In the rehearsals, Berlioz pioneered the practice of orchestral sectionals, rehearsing the different sections of the orchestra separately to better prepare them for the challenging piece. This was followed by two full orchestra rehearsals to polish up the details. It was first performed in three concerts conducted by Berlioz at the [[Conservatoire de Paris|Paris Conservatoire]] with an orchestra of 100 instruments and 101 voicesHoloman (1989), p. 201. on 24 November, 1 December and 15 December 1839, before capacity audiences that comprised much of the Parisian [[intelligentsia]]. Another notable audience member was [[Richard Wagner]], who would later note the influence of the symphony on his opera ''[[Tristan und Isolde]]''. Reactions to the piece were quite varied, as could be expected for a radical work. However, it was widely acknowledged that Berlioz had scored a major triumph in these first performances; a "tour de force such as only my system of sectional rehearsals could have achieved". Berlioz comments: "The work as it was then [in 1839] was performed three times at the Conservatoire under my direction and, each time, appeared to be a genuine success. But I felt at once that much would have to be changed, and I went over it carefully and critically from every point of view."Berlioz; Cairns (2002), p. 245. He continued to revise the work, a few instances upon the suggestions of critics, but generally by his own judgement. A premiere of a later revision (including cuts and changes to the ''Prologue'', ''Queen Mab Scherzo'', and the ''Finale'') was held in [[Vienna]] on 2 January 1846, the first performance since 1839 and the first abroad. After hearing a complete performance in Vienna on 26 January 1846, Berlioz took the opportunity to make major revisions before a performance scheduled for the following April in [[Prague]]. He accepted advice from several confidants and advisers, rewriting the [[coda (music)|coda]] of the ''Queen Mab Scherzo'', shortening Friar Laurence's narrative at the end, deleting a lengthy second ''Prologue'' at the beginning of the second half, and introducing musical foreshadowing in the first prologue. The full score was not published until 1847.[http://www.hberlioz.com/Scores/sromeo.htm HBerlioz.com | Berlioz reference site] Reflecting on the first performances, Berlioz commented in his memoirs:
The work is enormously difficult to perform. It poses problems of every kind, problems inherent in the form and in the style and only to be solved by long and patient rehearsal, impeccably directed. To be well done, it needs first-rate performers—players, singers, conductor—intent on preparing it with as much care as a new opera is prepared in a good opera house, in fact almost as if it were to be performed by heart.Berlioz; Cairns (2002), p. 246.
==Instrumentation== The [[Sheet music|score]] calls for: *[[piccolo]], 2 [[flute]]s, 2 [[oboe]]s (one doubling [[cor anglais]]), 2 [[clarinet]]s, 4 [[bassoon]]s *4 [[French horn|horns]], 2 [[cornet]]s, 2 [[trumpet]]s, 3 [[trombone]]s, [[bass tuba]] *2 pairs of [[timpani]], 2 [[snare drum]]s, [[bass drum]], [[cymbal]]s, [[crotales]] *2 [[harp]]s *[[String section|strings]] ==Music== Structurally and musically, ''Roméo et Juliette'' is most indebted to [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]]'s [[Symphony No. 9 (Beethoven)|9th symphony]] – not just due to the use of soloists and [[choir]], but in factors such as the weight of the vocal contribution being in the finale, and also in aspects of the orchestration such as the theme of the [[trombone]] recitative at the ''Introduction''. The roles of Roméo and Juliette are represented by the [[orchestra]], and the narrative aspects by the voices. [[Hector Berlioz|Berlioz]]'s reasoning follows:
If, in the famous garden and cemetery scenes, the dialogue of the two lovers, Juliet's [[aside]]s, and Romeo's passionate outbursts are not sung, if the duets of love and despair are given to the orchestra, the reasons for this are numerous and easy to understand. First, and this reason alone would be sufficient, it is a symphony and not an opera. Second, since duets of this nature have been treated vocally a thousand times by the greatest masters, it was wise as well as unusual to attempt another means of expression.[http://hector.ucdavis.edu/Berlioz2003/Texts/79R&JObs.htm ''Roméo et Juliette'': Berlioz's Avant-propos and Observations]
The vocal forces are used sparingly throughout, until they are fully deployed in the finale. The exceptional virtuosity deployed in the orchestral writing seems particularly appropriate for the dedicatee of the work, Paganini himself, who was never able to hear it, much to Berlioz's regret. Further examples of Berlioz's inventiveness are shown in the use of thematic links throughout the piece, somewhat laying the ground for the Wagnerian [[leitmotif]], for example the last solo notes of the [[oboe]] which follow Juliet's suicide echo a phrase from the earlier funeral procession when she was thought to be dead. Berlioz signed and dated his autograph on 8 September 1839. The final score was dedicated to Paganini.[http://www.kennedy-center.org/calendar/?fuseaction=composition&composition_id=3150 Programme notes], [[Kennedy Center]] The stylistic links of the work with Beethoven before (and [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]] after) could not be stronger. From Beethoven, Berlioz learned the very notion of programmatic music. He saw in the [[Symphony No. 6 (Beethoven)|Pastoral symphony]] how music might be depictive without being naïve, in the symphonic [[scherzo|scherzi]] how the delicate ''[[Queen Mab]]'' might best be evoked, and in the [[Symphony No. 9 (Beethoven)|9th symphony]] how effective a choral finale could be. He sensed Beethoven's flexibility with regard to number of movements and the performing force. ==Influence== From ''Roméo et Juliette'' [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]] absorbed so much about the ideals of dramatic music that the work can be considered a major influence on ''[[Tristan und Isolde]]''. When Wagner first heard the work in 1839 he said it made him feel like a schoolboy at [[Hector Berlioz|Berlioz]]'s side. ''Roméo et Juliette'' was also the work of Berlioz's that Wagner knew best. Indeed, their second and last meeting was on the occasion of a performance of the work in London in 1855. Wagner learned something of melodic flexibility and perhaps even a mastery of the orchestral force from Berlioz. He may have absorbed more specific features: the close relationship of the first few bars of the [[Tristan chord|''Tristan'' prelude]] to the opening of the second movement of ''Roméo et Juliette'' has been suggested. Moreover, in 1860, he sent Berlioz the published full score of ''Tristan und Isolde'' inscribed merely: Au grand et cher auteur de ''Roméo et Juliette'' L'auteur reconnaissant de ''Tristan et Isolde''. (To the great and dear author of ''Romeo and Juliet'' from the grateful author of ''Tristan and Isolde''.)Cairns (1999), p. 650.{{Clear|left}} Beyond the influence on Wagner's music drama, the piece pushed the limits of the contemporary orchestra's capabilities, in terms of colour, [[program music|programmatic]] scope and individual virtuosity. While this applies to much of Berlioz's music, it is even more true for ''Roméo et Juliette'', written at the height of his powers and ambition. Its vivid scene-setting surpasses many [[opera]]s, which constitutes an enormous success on Berlioz's part. [[Franz Liszt]] also recognised the significance of Berlioz as a progressive composer, and championed his music. ==Structure== '''Part I''' 1. Introduction: ''Combats'' (Combat) – ''Tumulte'' (Tumult) – :''Intervention du prince'' (Intervention of the prince) – :''Prologue'' – Strophes – Scherzetto '''Part II''' 2. ''Roméo seul'' (Romeo alone) – ''Tristesse'' (Sadness) – :''Bruits lointains de concert et de bal'' (Distant sounds from the concert and the ball) – :''Grande fête chez Capulet'' (Great banquet at the Capulets) 3. ''Scène d'amour'' (Love scene) – ''Nuit serène'' (Serene night) – :Le jardin de Capulet silencieux et déserte'' (The Capulets' garden silent and deserted) – :''Les jeunes Capulets sortant de la fête en chantant des réminiscences de la musique du bal'' (The young Capulets leaving the banquet singing snatches of music from the ball) 4. Scherzo: ''La reine Mab, reine des songes'' (Queen Mab, the queen of dreams – the Queen Mab Scherzo) '''Part III''' 5. ''Convoi funèbre de Juliette'' (Funeral cortège for the young Juliet): ''"Jetez des fleurs pour la vierge expirée"'' ("Throw flowers for the dead virgin") 6. ''Roméo au tombeau des Capulets'' (Romeo at the tomb of the Capulets) – :Invocation: ''Réveil de Juliette'' (Juliet awakes) – ''Joie délirante, désespoir'' (Delirious joy, despair) – :''Dernières angoisses et mort des deux amants'' (Last throes and death of the two lovers) 7. Finale: :''La foule accourt au cimetière'' (The crowd rushes to the graveyard) – :''Des Capulets et des Montagus'' (Fight between the Capulets and Montagues) – :''Récitatif et Air du Père Laurence'' (Friar Lawrence's recitative and aria) Aria: ''"Pauvres enfants que je pleure"'' ("Poor children that I weep for") – :''Serment de réconciliation'' (Oath of reconciliation) Oath: ''"Jurez donc par l'auguste symbole"'' ("Swear by the revered symbol") ==Recordings== ===Complete=== *''Roméo et Juliette'': [[Gladys Swarthout]], John Garris, [[Nicola Moscona]]. [[File:Mažasisteatras2010 02 09Vilnius02.JPG|thumb|Former building of Rūta Society (now the State Small Theatre of Vilnius on the [[Gediminas Avenue]])]] '''Rūta Society''' ({{lang-lt|Vilniaus lietuvių kultūros draugija „Rūta“}}) was a [[Lithuania]]n cultural society in [[Vilnius]] (Vilna, Wilno), then part of the [[Russian Empire]], active from 1909 to the outbreak of [[World War I]] in 1914. It organized various events, including lectures, literary evenings, and musical performances, but it is most noted for its contribution to the development of the Lithuanian theater. In total, Rūta staged about 50 plays.<ref name=baski/>
==History and choir== The official permission to establish Rūta was received on 25 September 1908 and the founding meeting took place on 11 January 1909.<ref name=prusi/> At that time the society registered 66 members and elected a 12-member board, which included {{illm|Jonas Masiulis|lt}} (chairman), {{illm|Andrius Domaševičius|lt}} (vice-chairman), [[Mykolas Sleževičius]] (secretary), [[Jonas Basanavičius]], {{illm|Jurgis Šlapelis|lt}}.<ref name=prusi/> The membership dues were set at a minimum of four [[Russian rubles|rubles]] per year.<ref name=griga/> Sleževičius was the main driving force behind the society – he established a cultural society of the same name as a law student at the [[Odessa University]]. During the first year, the number of members grew to 192<ref name=prusi/> and the society held 33 evenings (mostly dance) and four lectures.<ref name=griga/>
The society had a group for singers, dancers, music players, and theater performers.<ref name=manel/> Most performances were open to the public. The society had a choir (about 50 members) which performed works by Lithuanian composers ([[Mikalojus Konstantinas Čiurlionis]], [[Juozas Naujalis]], [[Mikas Petrauskas]], [[Česlovas Sasnauskas]], [[Stasys Šimkus]])<ref name=manel/> as well as foreign composers ([[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]], [[Robert Schumann]], [[Jules Massenet]]).<ref name=povil/> In 1910, a Latvian subsidiary of the [[Gramophone Company]] recorded ''[[Tautiška giesmė]]'' and eight other patriotic songs.<ref name=patef/><ref name=nakie/> The singers were little trained – their voices were loud but enthusiastic.<ref name=nakie/> Another recording of 20 songs by Lithuanian composers was made in 1914.<ref name=manel/> Together with a [[symphonic orchestra]], the choir performed [[cantata]] "De profundis" by Čiurlionis in 1913.<ref name=manel/>
==Theater== The theater group with [[Mykolas Sleževičius]] was particularly active.<ref name=prusi/> It also included {{illm|Gabrielius Landsbergis-Žemkalnis|lt}}, [[Antanas Žmuidzinavičius]], and others.<ref name=prusi/> The [[Backdrop (theater)|backdrop]] was painted by [[Mikalojus Konstantinas Čiurlionis]] in June 1909. It has survived and is preserved at the [[M. K. Čiurlionis National Art Museum]]<ref name=limis/> and commemorated by a fresco inside the former theater of Rūta.<ref name=jakim/> The group, which was active even before Rūta was officially organized, staged several plays, most notably historical dramas ''Mindaugis, Lietuvos karalius'' by [[Juliusz Słowacki]] (''[[Mindaugas]], [[King of Lithuania]]''; premiered on 27 April 1908) and ''Živilė, duktė Karijoto'' by Vincas Nagornoskis (''Živilė, Daughter of [[Karijotas]]''; premiered on 4 January 1909).<ref name=prusi/> The plays had to be approved by Russian censors who diligently removed any anti-Russian sentiments.<ref name=avizi/> As a result, many plays were significantly cut. For example, ''Živilė, duktė Karijoto'' lost the entire first section and many scenes.<ref name=avizi/>
The theater shift from simple comedies to historical dramas revealed limitations of the amateur theater and the need of a professional Lithuanian theater.<ref name=trink03/> To that end, in September 1910, the theater group separated from Rūta and joined the theater group of the Lithuanian Mutual Relief Society of Vilnius (''Vilniaus lietuvių savitarpinės pašalpos draugija'') to form an independent Lithuanian Artists' Union of Vilnius (''Vilniaus lietuvių artistų sąjunga'') which two years later established the first [[theater company]].<ref name=trink15/> The union and the company closely cooperated with Rūta and staged many new plays. Lithuanian activists hoped that it would become the basis for the professional Lithuanian theater, but it faced financial difficulties and internal disagreements, paid no heed to theater education and hoped that practice would be enough.<ref name=trink15/> The last play, modernist ''The Snow'' by [[Stanisław Przybyszewski]], was performed on 10 May 1914. Further activities were disrupted by World War I.<ref name=trink15/>

Faktus galima išmesti iš knygos, bet ne iš istorijos |date=June–July 2013 |volume=6-7 |issue=46–47 |language=lt |journal=Apžvalga |page=54 |issn=1392-6721}}</ref> <ref name=griga>{{cite journal |first=Algirdas |last=Grigaravičius |url= http://www.tekstai.lt/component/content/article/7846-algirdas-grigaravicius-jonas-basanavicius-prie-lietuvisko-meno-istaku-vilniuje |language=lt |title=Jonas Basanavičius prie lietuviško meno ištakų Vilniuje |date=February 2015 |volume=2 |journal=Metai |issn=0134-3211 }}</ref> <ref name=jakim>{{cite web |first=Rūta |last=Jakimauskienė |date=21 April 2017 |url=https://www.15min.lt/kultura/naujiena/renginiai/aktore-valda-bickute-savaitgali-lydes-ekskursijas-po-vilniaus-mazaji-teatra-29-786668 |title=Aktorė Valda Bičkutė savaitgalį lydės ekskursijas po Vilniaus mažąjį teatrą |publisher=[[15 min]] |language=lt |accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref> <ref name=limis>{{cite web| url=https://www.limis.lt/detali-paieska/perziura/-/exhibit/preview/50000000015067?s_id=gG7MvMAcv89E5OsV&s_ind=200&valuable_type=EKSPONATAS |title=„Rūtos“ draugijos scenos uždanga |work=Lietuvos integrali muziejų informacinė sistema |language=lt |publisher=Lithuanian Art Museum |accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref> <ref name=manel>{{cite encyclopedia |title=Rūta |encyclopedia=Lietuvos istorija. Enciklopedinis žinynas |editor-first1=Eugenijus |editor-last1=Manelis |editor-first2=Antanas |editor-last2=Račis |volume=II |publisher=[[Mokslo ir enciklopedijų leidybos centras]] |url=https://www.vle.lt/Straipsnis/ruta-81784 |year=2011 |isbn=978-5-420-01765-4 |language=lt |page=760}}</ref> <ref name=nakie>{{cite journal| first=Austė |last=Nakienė |url=http://www.llti.lt/failai/15_Nakienes.pdf |title=Tradicija ir inovacija : XX amžiaus pradžioje įamžinta lietuviška muzika ir Mikalojaus Konstantino Čiurlionio tautinės muzikos vizija |language=lt |issn=1392-2831 |journal=Tautosakos darbai |volume=XXXIX |year=2010 |page=157}}</ref> <ref name=patef>{{cite web| url=http://www.patefonas.lt/?page_id=478 |title=Istorija |language=lt |accessdate=6 May 2017 |year=2010 |website=Patefonas.lt}}</ref> <ref name=povil>{{cite book| first= Rima |last=Povilionienė |title=Sounds, Societies, Significations: Numanistic Approaches to Music |chapter=Music as National Identity Manifesto: The Musical Repertoire of Lithuanian Evenings at the Beginning of the 20th Century |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a4bgDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA81 |page=81 |publisher=Springer |year=2017 |isbn=9783319470603 }}</ref> <ref name=prusi>{{cite journal| first=Konstantinas |last=Prušinskas |title=Mykolas Sleževičius: politikas, visuomenės veikėjas, teatralas |url=http://samogitia.mch.mii.lt/ZZ_2014_1/ZZ_2014_Nr.1_p14-19.pdf| language=lt |journal= Žemaičių žemė |year=2014 |volume=1 |issn=1392-2610}}</ref> <ref name=trink03>{{cite journal |first= Šarūnė |last=Trinkūnaitė |title=Lietuvių mėgėjų teatras tautinio sąjūdžio laikais. (XIX a. pabaiga – XX a. pradžia) |url=http://etalpykla.lituanistikadb.lt/fedora/get/LT-LDB-0001:J.04~2003~1367159417801/DS.002.0.01.ARTIC |language=lt |page=15 |issn=1392-1002 |journal=Menotyra |year=2003 |volume=4 |issue=33}}</ref> <ref name=trink15>{{cite journal |first= Šarūnė |last=Trinkūnaitė |url=http://xn--urnalai-cxb.lmta.lt/wp-content/uploads/2015/Ars-et-praxis-III-Trink%C5%ABnait%C4%97.pdf |title=Vilniaus lietuvių dramos artistų bendrovės sutartis: teatro atnaujinimo viltys ir utopijos | language=lt |journal=Ars et praxis |year=2015 |volume=III |issn=2351-4744 |pages=160–163}}</ref> }}

{{see also|Memories of August 1914}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} [[File:Little Giant Girl, Albion House.jpg|thumb|Little Girl Giant on 21 April in front of [[Albion House, Liverpool|Albion House]] – the former headquarters of [[White Star Line]]]] [[File:Sea Odyssey, Uncle giant, Dale Street, Friday (1).jpg|thumb|The Giant Uncle on [[Dale Street]], 20 April]] [[File:Sea Odyssey, River Mersey.jpg|thumb|All three giants leaving Liverpool aboard a boat on 22 April]] [[File:Sea Odyssey, spectators.jpg|thumb|Spectators inside [[Mann Island Buildings|Mann Island Building 3]]]] '''Sea Odyssey: Giant Spectacular''' was a three-day outdoor [[performance art]] event featuring giant [[marionette]]s, that took place in [[Liverpool]], England, from 20 to 22 April 2012.<ref name=BBC-Day1>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-merseyside-17777090 |title=Giant puppets in Liverpool for Sea Odyssey Titanic event |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=20 April 2012 |accessdate=22 April 2012}}</ref>
It was designed and operated by French street theatre company [[Royal de Luxe]], and featured three giants, the 9-metre (30-foot) tall Little Giant Girl, the 15-metre (50-foot) tall Giant Uncle, and the girl's dog, Xolo.<ref name=Wake>{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-news/regional-news/2012/04/20/sea-odyssey-little-giant-girl-wakes-up-to-start-three-day-liverpool-spectacular-100252-30801720 |title=Sea Odyssey: Little Giant Girl wakes up to start three-day Liverpool spectacular|publisher=[[Liverpool Daily Post]]|date=20 April 2012|accessdate=23 April 2012}}</ref>
It was estimated that, over the course of the three days, 600,000 people watched the event<ref name=BBC-Day3>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-merseyside-17798401 |title=Liverpool giants: Sea Odyssey Titanic event ends |publisher=BBC |date=22 April 2012 |accessdate=22 April 2012}}</ref> whilst Liverpool City Council recorded a footfall in the main shopping district of 900,000.<ref name=councilstat>{{cite web|url=http://liverpool.gov.uk/news/details.aspx?id=214917|title=City on crest of a wave after Sea Odyssey|publisher=Liverpool City Council|date=25 April 2012|accessdate=30 May 2012}}</ref>
An independent report into the impact of Sea Odyssey concluded it was the most successful event in Liverpool’s history. The report showed that 800,000 people took part in the event, which resulted in an economic impact of £32 million.<ref name=councilstat2>{{cite web|url=http://liverpool.gov.uk/news/details.aspx?id=215928|title=Sea Odyssey success|publisher=Liverpool City Council|date=25 April 2012|accessdate=30 May 2012}}</ref>
==Event==
The event, staged to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the sinking of the [[RMS Titanic|RMS ''Titanic'']], was inspired by a letter written by a 10-year-old girl, May McMurray, in 1912 to her father William, a bedroom steward on the Titanic who did not survive the sinking. The letter did not arrive until after the Titanic sailed, and was returned to the sender and is now on display at Liverpool's Maritime Museum.<ref name=Inspired>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-merseyside-17729987 |title=Liverpool Sea Odyssey event inspired by Titanic letter |publisher=BBC |date=20 April 2012 |accessdate=23 April 2012}}</ref><ref name=May>{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-culture/liverpool-arts/2012/04/19/sea-odyssey-the-story-of-the-little-girl-who-inspired-liverpool-s-biggest-ever-street-theatre-event-99623-30779993/ |title=SEA ODYSSEY: The story of the little girl who inspired Liverpool’s biggest ever street theatre event |publisher=Liverpool Daily Post |date=19 April 2012 |accessdate=23 April 2012}}</ref><ref name=RDL_News>{{cite web |url=http://www.royal-de-luxe.com/en/news/ |title=Liverpool, "L’Odyssée de la mer" (in French)|publisher=Royal de Luxe, Nantes| date= |accessdate=23 April 2012}}</ref>
The cost of the event, estimated at £1.5m, was partly met by European legacy funding from Liverpool's 2008 Capital of Culture year. Early forecasts suggested it resulted in a £12 million boost to the city's economy.<ref name=Heart/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-merseyside-17812818 |title=Liverpool Sea Odyssey giant event's £12m economy boost |publisher=BBC |date=23 April 2012 |accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref><ref name=LCC>{{cite web |url=http://liverpool.gov.uk/news/details.aspx?id=214917 |title=City on crest of a wave after Sea Odyssey |publisher=Liverpool City Council |date=25 April 2012 |accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref>
With initial expectations of around 250,000 people attending,<ref name=BBC-Bringing>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17762154 |title=Bringing Liverpool's Sea Odyssey giants to life |publisher=BBC |date=20 April 2012|accessdate=22 April 2012}}</ref> immediately after the event it was estimated that 600,000 people watched the event over the three days.<ref name=BBC-Day3/><ref name=LCC/>
The show was led by Royal de Luxe's artistic director, Jean-Luc Courcoult, who celebrated its conclusion by jumping into the [[River Mersey]].<ref name=BBC-Day3/><ref name=Courcoult>{{cite web |url=http://www.royal-de-luxe.com/en/jean-luc-courcoult/ |title=Le metteur en scène, Jean-Luc Courcoult |publisher=Royal de Luxe, Nantes| date= |accessdate=23 April 2012}}</ref>
==Story==
The story, written by Jean-Luc Courcoult, envisages the girl's uncle, a diver, searching the wreck of the Titanic, and having found his brother's letter, coming ashore to bring it and the news of the ship's fate to his niece.<ref name=Story>{{cite web |url=http://www.giantspectacular.com/content/story |title=Liverpool Story |publisher=giantspectacular.com |date= |accessdate=23 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512125448/http://www.giantspectacular.com/content/story |archivedate=12 May 2012 }}</ref>
Rising from the water at Liverpool's [[Salthouse Dock]], the giant uncle wanders around the city in search of the girl, who simultaneously awakes in the city's [[Stanley Park, Liverpool|Stanley Park]] and, accompanied by her dog Xolo, sets out to look for her uncle.<ref name=Wake/>
The two miss each other several times, finally meeting up at the [[King's Dock, Port of Liverpool|King's Dock]] at the end of the second day of the event. The following day, the pair set out together for a final walk around the city centre, and then board a boat at [[Canning Dock]] and leave Liverpool via the River Mersey.<ref name=BBC-Day3/><ref name=Heart>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-merseyside-17806029 |title=Sea Odyssey giants capture Liverpool's heart |publisher=BBC |date=22 April 2012 |accessdate=23 April 2012}}</ref>
Between them, by the end of the three days, the giants covered a distance of 23 miles (37 km), taking in the areas around the football grounds of [[Liverpool F.C.]] and [[Everton F.C.]], the city centre, [[Pier Head]], [[Chinatown, Liverpool|Chinatown]], and the [[Albert Dock]] and King's Dock complexes.<ref name=Inspired/>
==Giants==
The giants taking part in the event comprised the Little Giant Girl, measuring 9 metres (30 feet), the Giant Uncle, measuring 15 metres (50 feet), and the girl's dog, Xolo. The girl and the uncle are constructed from [[Populus|poplar]] wood, [[Tilia|lime]] wood and steel, and have eyes made from street lights and hair made from horse hair. The dog, Xolo, is made from [[papier-mâché]] and steel. All three are controlled using ropes, pulleys and motors.<ref name=BBC-Day1/><ref name=BBC-Bringing/>
During the three days, the puppets, cranes, and other equipment required a team of 110 operators, who call themselves ''[[Lilliput and Blefuscu|Lilliputians]]'' after the characters from the 1726 [[Jonathan Swift]] novel ''[[Gulliver's Travels]]''. A total of 20 cranes were required to move them around the city.<ref name=BBC-Day1/> The uncle requires 31 people to control, with the girl operated by a team of 24 puppeteers, and the dog a team of 21.<ref name=BBC-Bringing/>
During the tour the giants were accompanied by a group of live musicians, and used a number of props, including the girl's boat, on which she sailed for part of her journey, her scooter, deck chair, bed, and radio.<ref name=Story/>
==See also== * ''[[La Princesse]]'', a 15-metre (50-foot) mechanical spider that roamed around Liverpool in 2008 * [[The Sultan's Elephant]], an event performed by Royal de Luxe in London in 2006, and in other cities * [[Memories of August 1914]], a later event in Liverpool with the same giant marionettes

{{italic title}} '''''Selected Essays, 1917-1932''''' is a collection of [[prose]] and [[literary criticism]] by [[T. S. Eliot]]. Eliot's work fundamentally changed literary thinking and ''Selected Essays'' provides both an overview and an in-depth examination of his theory.<ref name=BRags>[[BookRags]]: ''Selected Essays of T. S. Eliot, 1917-1932 Study Guide</ref> It was published in 1932 by his employers, [[Faber & Faber]], costing 12/6 (''2009: £{{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|0.625|1932|2009|r=-0}}}}'').<ref>''[[The Times]]'', 16 September 1932; ''Some New Books''</ref>
In addition to his poetry, by 1932, Eliot was already accepted as one of English Literature's most important critics. In this position he was instrumental in the reviving interest in the long‐neglected Jacobean playwrights.<ref name=OCAT>Eliot, T[homas] S[tearns]" The Oxford Companion to American Theatre, 3rd edn., Gerald Bordman and Thomas S. Hischak, eds., Oxford University Press 2004.</ref> ''A Dialogue on Dramatic Poetry'' was originally an addendum to Eliot's preface to Dryden's ''[[Essay of Dramatick Poesie]]'' (1928 reprint).<ref name=Baden>Richard Badenhausen ''T.S. Eliot and the art of collaboration'' [[Cambridge University Press]], 2004, {{ISBN|0-521-84123-2}}</ref> Further essays include ''The Metaphysical Poets (1921)'' in which Eliot argued that a "[[dissociation of sensibility]]" set in... due to the influence of ... [[John Milton|Milton]] and [[Dryden]].<ref Name=ODQ>"T. S. Eliot" Oxford Dictionary of Quotations. by Elizabeth Knowles. Oxford University Press Inc. Oxford Reference Online. Oxford University Press.</ref> Furthermore the modern poet ‘must be difficult’... ‘to force, to dislocate if necessary, language into his meaning’.<ref>"Eliot, T. S." The Oxford Companion to English Literature. Edited by Dinah Birch. Oxford University Press Inc.</ref> ''Philip Massinger (1920)'' contains his [[aphorism]] "Immature poets imitate; mature poets steal".<ref Name=ODQ/>
Eliot converted to the [[Church of England]] and some of the essays expressed the form and discipline he felt necessary for fulfillment in his own life.<ref>Eliot, T[homas] S[tearns]" The Oxford Companion to American Literature. James D. Hart, ed., rev. Phillip W. Leininger. Oxford University Press 1995</ref> ''For Lancelot Andrewes (1926)'', examines [[Lancelot Andrewes|Andrewes]], a 17th-century Anglican bishop whose Eliot considers an important figure in history of the church, distinguished for the quality of his thoughts and prose.<ref name=Lance>"For Lancelot Andrewes" The Oxford Companion to American Literature. James D. Hart, ed., rev. Phillip W. Leininger. Oxford University Press 1995</ref> In ''The Humanism of Irving Babbitt (1927)'', Eliot posits that [[Irving Babbitt|Babbitt]]'s faith in civilization must have a discipline derived from dogmatic religious authority.<ref name=Lance/>
==Reception== ''Selected Essays'' was placed fourth in the [[Intercollegiate Studies Institute]]'s [[Fifty Best Books of the Century]] and sixth in [[Modern Library]]'s Best 20th-Century Nonfiction.<ref>[http://www.modernlibrary.com/top-100/100-best-nonfiction/ 100 Best Nonfiction] —Modern Library</ref>
==Contents== '''I''' *[[Tradition and the Individual Talent (1917)]] *The Function of Criticism (1923) '''II''' *[[Wikisource:The Sacred Wood/"Rhetoric" and Poetic Drama|"Rhetoric" and Poetic Drama (1919)]] *A Dialogue on Dramatic Poetry (1928) *[[wikisource:The Sacred Wood/Euripides and Professor Murray|Euripides and Professor Murray (1918)]] *[[Seneca the Younger|Seneca]] in Elizabethan Translation (1927) '''III''' *Four Elizabethan Dramatists (1924) *[[Christopher Marlowe]] (1918) *[[Shakespeare]] and the [[Stoicism]] of Seneca (1927) *[[Hamlet and his Problems (1919)]] *[[Wikisource:The Sacred Wood/Ben Jonson|Ben Johnson (1919)]] *[[Thomas Middleton]] (1927) *[[Thomas Heywood]] (1931) *[[Cyril Tourneur]] (1931) *[[John Ford (dramatist)|John Ford]] (1932) *[[Wikisource:The Sacred Wood/Philip Massinger|Philip Massinger (1920)]] '''IV''' *[[Wikisource:The Sacred Wood/Dante|Dante (1929)]] '''V''' *[http://www.cola.wright.edu/Dept/ENG/limouze/eliotmetaphys.htm The Metaphysical Poets (1921)] *[[Andrew Marvell]] (1921) *John Dryden (1922) *[[William Blake]] (1920) *[[Wikisource:The Sacred Wood/Swinburne As Poet|Swinburne as Poet (1920)]] '''VI''' *Lancelot Andrewes (1926) *[[John Bramhall]] (1927) *Thoughts after Lambeth (1931) '''VII''' *[[Baudelaire]] (1930) *[[Matthew Arnold|Arnold]] and [[Walter Pater|Pater]] (1930) *[[Francis Herbert Bradley]] (1926) *[[Marie Lloyd]] (1923) *[[Wilkie Collins]] and [[Dickens]] (1927) *The Humanism of Irving Babbitt (1927) *Second Thoughts on Humanism (1929) *[[Charles Whibley]] (1931)

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{primary|date=April 2015}} The '''Society of Illustrators of Los Angeles''' (SILA) was founded in 1953 by a group of [[Southern California]] artists and designers "...to promote the professional status of illustration art as well as foster both philanthropic and educational goals".<ref>[http://www.si-la.org Society of Illustrators of Los Angeles]</ref>
A scholarship program is provided, and annual awards are presented to illustrators for their works. The top annual award, named after the first president of SILA, is the "'''[[Joseph Morgan Henninger]] Award'''".
The Society maintains an association with the [[United States Air Force]] (USAF) whereby members may contribute appropriate art to the USAF Art Collection.<ref>[http://www.afapo.hq.af.mil/Presentation/main/Index.cfm United States Air Force Art Collection]</ref> Contributing artists are flown at government expense to a show of their works and receive awards for their contributions. The artists retain copyright to their works.
The Society supports an active blog to keep members informed and conducts classes and workshops at Pop Secret Gallery.<ref>[http://hometown-pasadena.com/events/pop-comedy/131118 "POP! Comedy"] ''Hometown Pasadena''. Retrieved 6 July 2017.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

The '''Symphony No. 3''' is a composition for [[orchestra]] by the American composer [[Ned Rorem]]. The work was first performed by the [[New York Philharmonic]] under the direction of [[Leonard Bernstein]] at [[Carnegie Hall]] on April 16, 1959.<ref name="Score">{{Cite web |last=Rorem |first=Ned |authorlink=Ned Rorem |date=1958 |title=Symphony No. 3 |publisher=[[Boosey & Hawkes]] |url=http://www.boosey.com/cr/music/Ned-Rorem-Symphony-No-3/5107 |accessdate=November 3, 2016}}</ref>
==Composition==
===Structure=== The Symphony No. 3 has a duration of roughly 24 minutes and is cast in five [[Movement (music)|movements]]: #Passacaglia #Allegro molto vivace #Largo #Andante #Allegro molto
The movements were not composed in chronological order; Rorem wrote the "Allegro molto vivace" first, the "Pasacaglia" second, the "Andante" third, the "Largo" fourth, and the "Allegro molto" last. Rorem called the first movement "a slow overture in the grand style." The second movement, which the composer described as "a brisk and jazzy dance," had originally been composed as a piece for two pianos eight years prior. Rorem described the third movements as "a short, passionate page about somnambulism, full of dynamic contrast, and coming from afar." He called the fourth movement "a farewell to France" and described the fifth and final movement as a miniature [[Concerto for Orchestra]].<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=ROREM, N.: Symphonies Nos. 1-3 (Bournemouth Symphony, Serebrier) |date=June 2003 |url=http://www.naxos.com/mainsite/blurbs_reviews.asp?item_code=8.559149&catNum=559149&filetype=About%20this%20Recording&language=English# |access-date=November 3, 2016 |first=José |last=Serebrier |authorlink=José Serebrier |type=CD liner |publisher=[[Naxos Records]]}}</ref>
===Instrumentation=== The work is scored for a large orchestra consisting of two [[Western concert flute|flutes]], [[piccolo]], two [[oboe]]s, [[cor anglais]], two [[clarinet]]s, [[bass clarinet]], two [[bassoon]], [[contrabassoon]], four [[French horn|horns]], three [[trumpet]]s, three [[trombone]]s, [[tuba]], [[timpani]], percussion, [[Pedal harp|harp]], [[celesta]], [[piano]], and [[String section|strings]].<ref name="Score" />
==Reception== Though rarely performed, the symphony has received praise from music critics. Andrew Farach-Colton of ''[[Gramophone (magazine)|Gramophone]]'' praised the symphony, writing, "The first movement passacaglia is simply gorgeous – listen beginning at 3'15" to hear how much Rorem gleaned from [[Maurice Ravel|Ravel]] – and the two adjacent slow movements are also exquisitely coloured. I find the manic, [[Leonard Bernstein|Bernstein]]-esque scherzo uncharacteristically coarse, though the finale more than makes up for it, providing exhilaration and plenty of orchestral razzle-dazzle without a trace of raucousness."<ref>{{cite web |last=Farach-Colton |first=Andrew |title=Rorem Three Symphonies |work=[[Gramophone (magazine)|Gramophone]] |date=October 2003 |url=http://www.gramophone.co.uk/review/rorem-three-symphonies |accessdate=November 3, 2016}}</ref>
Reviewing a 2000 performance at the [[Curtis Institute of Music]], [[Allan Kozinn]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' similarly observed, "It is in some ways very much of its time, in that it embodies an updated form of [[Impressionism in music|Impressionism]], filtered through an American urbanity, as well as stretches of jazzy theatricality in the style of Bernstein (who conducted this work's premiere) and even a trace of [[Aaron Copland|Copland]]'s faux-Western accent." He added, "It may also have been a manifesto of sorts, an assertive declaration that tonality and conventional structures still had something to say at a time when [[Serialism]] was ascendant. The work has not been heard very frequently, but today its tonal, eclectic personality is current again: tonality is now acceptable everywhere, and composers 40 years younger than Mr. Rorem (who is a young-looking 76) write music that makes similar allusions." Kozinn also called it "a demanding work" and wrote, "Its dense, outgoing sections require power and assurance, and its more graceful slow movements require delicacy and a fine balance."<ref>{{cite web |last=Kozinn |first=Allan |authorlink=Allan Kozinn |title=MUSIC REVIEW; When Tonality Refused to Stay Quiet |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 6, 2000 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/06/arts/music-review-when-tonality-refused-to-stay-quiet.html |accessdate=November 3, 2016}}</ref>

{{more footnotes|date=August 2011}} '''The New York Intellectuals''' were a group of American writers and literary critics based in [[New York City]] in the mid-20th century. Mostly Jewish, they advocated [[left-wing politics]] but were also firmly [[anti-Stalinist left|anti-Stalinist]]. The group is known for having sought to integrate [[literary theory]] with [[Marxism]] and [[Socialism]] while rejecting Soviet [[Communism]] as a workable or acceptable political model.
[[Trotskyism]] emerged as the most chosen standpoint among these anti-Stalinist Marxists. [[Irving Howe]], [[Seymour Martin Lipset]], [[Leslie Fiedler]] and [[Nathan Glazer]] were members of the Trotskyist [[Young People's Socialist League]].<ref>Alexander Bloom: Prodigal Sons. The New York Intellectuals and Their World, Oxford University Press: NY / Oxford 1986, p. 109.</ref>
==Overview== Writers often identified as members of this group include [[Hannah Arendt]], [[William Barrett (philosopher)|William Barrett]], [[Daniel Bell]], [[Saul Bellow]], [[Elliot E. Cohen|Elliot Cohen]], [[Midge Decter]], [[Leslie Fiedler]], [[Nathan Glazer]], [[Clement Greenberg]], [[Paul Goodman (writer)|Paul Goodman]], [[Richard Hofstadter]], [[Sidney Hook]], [[Irving Howe]], [[Alfred Kazin]], [[Irving Kristol]], [[Seymour Martin Lipset]], [[Mary McCarthy (author)|Mary McCarthy]], [[Dwight Macdonald]], [[William Phillips (editor)|William Phillips]], [[Norman Podhoretz]], [[Philip Rahv]], [[Harold Rosenberg]], [[Isaac Rosenfeld]], [[Delmore Schwartz]], [[Susan Sontag]], [[Harvey Swados]], [[Diana Trilling]], [[Lionel Trilling]], and [[Robert Warshow]].
Many of these intellectuals were educated at [[City College of New York]] ("Harvard of the Proletariat"), [[New York University]] and [[Columbia University]] in the 1930s, and associated in the next two decades with the left-wing political journals ''[[Partisan Review]]'' and ''[[Dissent (American magazine)|Dissent]]'', as well as the then-left-wing but later neoconservative-leaning journal ''[[Commentary (magazine)|Commentary]]''. Writer [[Nicholas Lemann]] has described these intellectuals as "the American [[Bloomsbury Group|Bloomsbury]]".
Some, including Kristol, Hook, and Podhoretz, later became key figures in the development of [[Neoconservatism]].
==See also== *[[Frankfurt School]] *[[Trotskyism]] *[[Anti-Stalinist left]]
==References== {{Reflist}} *Bloom, Alexander. ''Prodigal Sons: The New York Intellectuals and Their World'', Oxford University Press, 1986, {{ISBN|0-19-503662-X}} *Cooney, Terry A. ''The Rise of the New York Intellectuals: Partisan Review and Its Circle, 1934-1945'', University of Wisconsin Press, 1986, {{ISBN|0-299-10710-8}} *Dorman, Joseph. ''Arguing the World: The New York Intellectuals in their Own Words''. New York: Free Press, 2000. {{ISBN|0-684-86279-4}}. *Jumonville, Neil. ''Critical Crossings: The New York Intellectuals in Postwar America'', University of California Press, 1991, {{ISBN|0-520-06858-0}} *Laskin, David. ''Partisans: Marriage, Politics, and Betrayal Among the New York Intellectuals'' University of Chicago Press, 2001, {{ISBN|0-226-46893-3}} *{{cite book | last = Wald | first = Alan M. | authorlink = Alan M. Wald | title = The New York Intellectuals: The Rise and Decline of the Anti-Stalinist Left from the 1930s to the 1980s | publisher = University of North Carolina Press | date = 1987 | ISBN = 0-8078-4169-2}}
==External links== * [http://www.robertfulford.com/Intellectuals.html Lives of the New York intellectuals] by [[Robert Fulford (journalist)|Robert Fulford]] in ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' * [http://www.cardus.ca/comment/article/199 The Failure of the New York Intellectuals] by [[Daniel Silliman]] in ''Comment'' * [https://www.pbs.org/arguing/ Arguing the World], the [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] documentary

{{Infobox book | name = The Otaku Encyclopedia | image = Otaku Encyclopedia cover.jpg | caption = Front cover of the book showing Moe-chan | author = Patrick W. Galbraith | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Japan | language = English | subject = [[otaku]] | genre = [[Encyclopedia]] | publisher = [[Kodansha]] | pub_date = 2009 | media_type = Print ([[Paperback]]) | pages = 248 | isbn = 978-4-7700-3101-3 | dewey = | congress = | oclc = }} '''''The Otaku Encyclopedia''''' is a 2009 [[encyclopedia]] written by Patrick Galbraith and published by Kodansha which provides an overview of [[anime and manga fandom]] topics,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/15059.html |title='The Otaku Encyclopedia' |publisher=ICv2 |date= |accessdate=2010-06-03}}</ref> and interviews and profiles of important people in Japanese fandom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://manga.about.com/od/recommendedreading/tp/MangaGiftBooks.htm |title=Manga Gift Books Guide|publisher=[[About.com]]|date=2009-12-04|accessdate=2010-06-03}}</ref>
==Content==
''The Otaku Encyclopedia'' consists of some 600 entries on the subculture concerned with [[anime]], [[manga]] and [[video game]]s, with 124 colour pages and 150 photographs. [[Frederik L. Schodt]] provides a foreword to the book.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icv2.com/articles/news/15059.html |title='The Otaku Encyclopedia' |publisher=ICv2 |date= |accessdate=2013-03-15}}</ref> A maid character called Moe-chan accompanies the reader through the book.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Otaku Encyclopedia|author=Patrick W. Galbraith|date=2009|publisher=Kodansha|page=4}}</ref> In addition to entries about the subculture, the encyclopedia contains interviews with a dozen different notable people. [[Kaichirō Morikawa]] who is an author, and lecturer at [[Meiji University]] talks about the [[otaku]] culture of [[Akihabara]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The Otaku Encyclopedia|author=Patrick W. Galbraith|date=2009|publisher=Kodansha|pages=14–16}}</ref> Anime director [[Yutaka Yamamoto]] talks about anime in general which include its fans and ones he has directed.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Otaku Encyclopedia|author=Patrick W. Galbraith|date=2009|publisher=Kodansha|pages=22–24}}</ref> As one of the main organizers of [[Comiket]], [[Koichi Ichikawa]] talks about the [[dōjinshi]] fair, including what lies ahead.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Otaku Encyclopedia|author=Patrick W. Galbraith|date=2009|publisher=Kodansha|pages=46–48}}</ref> Author [[Yunmao Ayakawa]] known for working as a journalist, and [[cosplay]]er, talks about cosplay and what got her into it.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Otaku Encyclopedia|author=Patrick W. Galbraith|date=2009|publisher=Kodansha|pages=54–56}}</ref> [[Bishojo]] model [[figurine]] sculptor [[Bome (sculptor)|BOME]] talks about and describes his career in model making.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Otaku Encyclopedia|author=Patrick W. Galbraith|date=2009|publisher=Kodansha|pages=74–77}}</ref> Expert [[gamer]] [[Haruna Anno]], who has been dubbed as "Queen of Retro games' in [[Tokyo]] talks about how otaku and gamers relate to one another as well as how she got into gaming.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Otaku Encyclopedia|author=Patrick W. Galbraith|date=2009|publisher=Kodansha|pages=86–89}}</ref> Singer [[Himeko Sakuragawa]] known for her single "Goin' to Akiba" talks about her life as an [[Japanese idol|Idoru]], and her experience with Akihabara.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Otaku Encyclopedia|author=Patrick W. Galbraith|date=2009|publisher=Kodansha|page=106}}</ref>
A list of recommended anime, video games, and [[Tokusatsu]] appears at the end of the book.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Otaku Encyclopedia|author=Patrick W. Galbraith|date=2009|publisher=Kodansha|pages=242–243}}</ref>
'''Interviews''':
*Hitomi *[[Ako Hazuki]] *[[Toshio Okada]] *[[Takashi Murakami]] *[[Shoko Nakagawa]]
==Development== Galbraith regards the book as being needed due to media coverage of [[Tsutomu Miyazaki]] informing people about Japanese fandom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/new-titles/adult-announcements/article/29803-geek-speak-japanese-style--e2-80-98the-otaku-encyclopedia-e2-80-99-.html |title=Geek-Speak Japanese Style: ‘The Otaku Encyclopedia’|publisher=[[Publishers Weekly]]|date=2009-10-27 |accessdate=2010-06-04}}</ref>
==Reception== Scott Green regards ''The Otaku Encyclopedia'' as not being "disposable criticism".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aintitcool.com/node/42408 |title=AICN Anime - Gantz, Otaku Encyclopedia, New Imagi Astro Boy Footage, New Priest Casting, Battle Angel Sighting? Macross and More|publisher=[[Ain't It Cool News]]|date= |accessdate=2010-06-03}}</ref> Mark Schilling, writing for ''[[The Japan Times]],'' regards the encyclopedia's goal as being to "supply facts about the objects of obsession, while opening windows into the mysterious culture that produced them.", saying that the book does not have enough "critical distance or analysis".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fb20090726a1.html |title=The quirky terrain of an otaku mind |publisher=[[The Japan Times]]|date=2009-07-26 |accessdate=2010-06-03}}</ref> Brian Ruh feels that although the book tries to be broad in its scope, it is written from a fan perspective and shows that Galbraith is primarily a "moe otaku".<ref>{{cite web |last=Ruh |first=Brian |url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/brain-diving/otaku-where-art-thou/2010-12-14 |title=Otaku, Where Art Thou? - Brain Driving |work=Anime News Network |date=2010-12-14 }}</ref>

Reitzel | media_type = Print | pub_date = 1863 | english_pub_date = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
"'''The Teapot'''" ([[Danish language|Danish]]: ''Theepotten'') is a literary [[fairy tale]] by Danish [[poet]] and [[author]] [[Hans Christian Andersen]] about a teapot and her adventures. The tale was first published 1863 and demonstrates the Andersen's talent for investing ordinary household objects with life, character, and personality.
== Plot summary == A porcelain teapot rules the tea table. She is very proud of her handle and spout, but not quite so proud of her lid (which is cracked). She is very proud of holding the tea leaves and of being the one to pour forth her contents for thirsty humankind. One day, the teapot is dropped and the handle and spout are broken. She is given to a beggar woman who fills her with soil and plants a flowering bulb within her. The teapot then feels a happiness she has never known. At the last, the teapot is broken in two, the bulb removed to a bigger pot, and the teapot thrown away. She cherishes her memories.
== Publication history== [[Image:teapot Pedersen 01.jpg|thumb|Illustration by [[Lorenz Frølich]], an early illustrator of Andersen's works]] The tale was first published December 1863 in ''Folkekalender for Danmark''. The work was republished 12 December 1871 in the fourth volume of ''Fairy Tales and Stories. 1871.''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.andersen.sdu.dk/vaerk/register/info_e.html?vid=160 |publisher=Hans Christian Andersen Center |title=Hans Christian Andersen: The Teapot}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Children's literature}} *[[List of works by Hans Christian Andersen]]

{{Intellectual property}} '''Trade dress''' is a legal [[term of art]] that generally refers to characteristics of the visual appearance of a product or its packaging (or even the design of a building) that signify the source of the product to consumers.{{cite book |first=Robert P. |last=Merges |first2=Peter S. |last2=Menell |authorlink3=Mark A. Lemley |first3=Mark A. |last3=Lemley |title=Intellectual Property in the New Technological Age |edition=4th rev. |year=2007 |location=New York |publisher=Wolters Kluwer |isbn=978-0-7355-6989-8 |page=29 }} Trade dress is a form of [[intellectual property]]. == India == The new ''Trade Marks Act'', 1997, which came into force in September 2003 introduced a new legal definition of a trade mark, which, in part, encompasses almost all the elements of trade dress as defined by the US law.[http://indialawjournal.com/volume1/issue_4/article_by_purnime.html "Trade dress protection for 'look and feel' of the Website"] ''India Law Journal'' (retrieved October 13, 2015) == United Kingdom == {{main|Passing off}} Trade dress can be protected as getup under the law of [[passing off]] in the UK. Passing off is a common law remedy for protecting an unregistered [[trademark]].{{cite web|last1=Clark|first1=Birgit|last2=Hitchens|first2=Ben|title=United Kingdom: The perils and powers of passing off|url=http://www.worldtrademarkreview.com/Magazine/Issue/54/Country-correspondents/The-perils-and-powers-of-passing-off|website=World Trademark Review|publisher=Globe Business Media Group|accessdate=12 September 2017}} Getup, packaging, business strategy, marketing techniques, advertisement themes etc. can also be protected under passing off. ==United States== Trade dress protection is intended to protect consumers from packaging or appearance of products that are designed to imitate other products; to prevent a consumer from buying one product under the belief that it is another.{{cite web|last1=Larson|first1=Aaron|title=Trademark Law|url=https://www.expertlaw.com/library/intellectual_property/trademark_law.html|website=ExpertLaw|accessdate=12 September 2017|date=7 November 2014}}Merges at 29 For example, the shape, color, and arrangement of the materials of a children's line of clothing can be protectable trade dress (though, the design of the garments themselves is not protected),''Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Samara Bros., Inc.'', 529 U.S. 205 (2000), https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/99-150.ZS.html as can the design of a magazine cover,''Reader’s Digest Ass’n v. Conservative Digest'', 821 F.2d 800 (D.C. Cir. 1987), http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F2/821/821.F2d.800.86-7004.86-5495.html the appearance and décor of a chain of Mexican-style restaurants,{{cite web|title=Two Pesos, Inc. v. Taco Cabana, Inc., 505 US 763, 112 S. Ct. 2753, 120 L. Ed. 2d 615 (1992)|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=12034599115584297601|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google|accessdate=12 September 2017}} and a method of displaying wine bottles in a wine shop.{{cite web|title=Best Cellars Inc. v. Grape Finds at Dupont, Inc.'', 90 F. Supp. 2d 431 (S.D.N.Y. 2000)|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=11114552205999238299|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google|accessdate=12 September 2017}} ===Statutory source=== In the U.S., like [[trademark]]s, a product’s trade dress is legally protected by the [[Lanham Act]], the federal statute which regulates trademarks and trade dress.The Lanham Act, http://www4.law.cornell.edu/uscode/15/ch22.html Under section 43(a) of the Lanham Act, a product's trade dress can be protected without formal registration with the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office]] (PTO).Merges at 650, Lanham Act 15 U.S.C. § 1125(a) In relevant part, section 43(a) states the following:
Any person who, on or in connection with any goods or services, or any container for goods, uses in commerce any word, term, name, symbol, or device, or any combination thereof, or any false designation of origin, false or misleading description of fact, or false or misleading representation of fact, which :(A) is likely to cause confusion, or to cause mistake, or to deceive [...] as to the origin, sponsorship, or approval of his or her goods, services, or commercial activities by another person, or :(B) in commercial advertising or promotion, misrepresents the nature, characteristics, qualities, or geographic origin of his or her or another person’s goods, services, or commercial activities, shall be liable in a civil action by any person who believes that he or she is likely to be damaged by such an act.{{usc|15|1125}}
This statute allows the owner of a particular trade dress ("container for goods") to sue an infringer (a person or entity who illegally copies that trade dress) for violating section 43(a) without registering that trade dress with any formal agency or system (unlike the registration and application requirements for enforcing other forms of intellectual property, such as patents). It is commonly seen as providing “federal common law” protection for trade dress (and trademarks).Merges at 650 ===Formal registration=== Trade dress may be registered with the PTO in either the [[Principal Register]] or the [[Supplemental Register]].PTO website, http://www.uspto.gov/ Although registration is not required for legal protection, registration offers several advantages. In the Principal Register, a registrant gains nationwide [[constructive use]] and [[constructive notice]], which prevent others from using or registering that registrant’s trade dress (without contesting the registration).Lanham Act § 7(c), 15 U.S.C. § 1057(c) Further, a registrant in the Principal Register gains [[incontestable status]] after five years, which eliminates many of the ways for another party to challenge the registration.Lanham Act § 15, 15 U.S.C. § 1057(c) Registration under the Supplemental Register allows the registrant to protect its trade dress in foreign countries, although the protections are much more limited than protections under the Principal Register in the U.S.Menell at 696 ===Legal requirements=== It can be difficult to obtain protection for trade dress, as applicants must prove that the design has secondary meaning to consumers and is then further limited by the functionality doctrine.{{cite journal|last1=Michael Best & Friedrich, LLP|title=Entrepreneur’s Guide to Intellectual Property – Blog Series: Protecting Your Products and Packaging with Trade Dress|journal=The National Law Review|date=10 June 2012|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/entrepreneur-s-guide-to-intellectual-property-blog-series-protecting-your-products-a|accessdate=17 November 2014|issn=2161-3362}} ====Functionality==== To gain registration in the Principal Register or common law protection under the Lanham Act, a trade dress must not be “functional.” That is, the configuration of shapes, designs, colors, or materials that make up the trade dress in question must not serve a utility or function outside of creating recognition in the consumer’s mind.{{cite web|title=Qualitex Co. v. Jacobson Products Co., 514 US 159, 115 S. Ct. 1300, 131 L. Ed. 2d 248 (1995)|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=17905304466595211702|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google|accessdate=12 September 2017}} For example, even though consumers associated a distinct spring design for wind resistant road signs with a particular company, the spring design was not protectable for trade dress purposes because the springs served the function of withstanding heavy wind conditions.{{cite web|title=TrafFix Devices, Inc. v. Marketing Displays, Inc., 532 US 23, 121 S. Ct. 1255, 149 L. Ed. 2d 164 (2001)|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=12704680276957369308|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google|accessdate=12 September 2017}} What is considered “functional” depends upon the specific product or thing sought to be protected.{{cite journal|last1=Feisthamel|first1=Karen|last2=Kelly|first2=Amy|last3=Sistek|first3=Johanna|title=Trade Dress: Best Practices for the Registration of Product Configuration Trade Dress with the USPTO|journal=The Trademark Reporter|date=November 2005|volume=95|issue=9|url=http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/thetmr95&div=121|accessdate=12 September 2017}} For example, the color red in a line of clothing may not be functional (and thus part of protectable trade dress) whereas the same color on a stop sign would be functional because the color red serves the function of putting drivers on alert (and thus would not be part of a protectable trade dress). ====Distinctiveness==== To gain registration in the Principal Register or common law protection under the Lanham Act, a trade dress must be “distinctive.” This means that consumers perceive a particular trade dress as identifying a source of a product. Claimed trade dress in the product design—as opposed to product packaging—context can no longer be "inherently distinctive"; it must acquire distinctiveness through "secondary meaning".{{cite web|title=''Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Samara Brothers, Inc.'', 529 U.S. 205, 120 S. Ct. 1339, 146 L. Ed. 182, 54 USPQ2d 1065 (2000)|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=11551321958641509496|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google|accessdate=12 September 2017}} Distinctiveness through secondary meaning means that although a trade dress is not distinctive on its face, the use of the trade dress in the market (the “[[Goodwill (accounting)|good will]]” of the trade dress) has created an association between that trade dress and a source in the mind of the consumer. Although the law is evolving, as it stands now, product packaging (including packaging in very general terms, such as a building’s décor) may be inherently distinctive. However, product design, that is the design or shape of the product itself, may not be inherently distinctive, and must acquire secondary meaning. ===Protection for electronic interfaces and websites=== Although the exact boundaries of protection are still uncertain, courts are beginning to allow trade dress protection for the overall “[[look and feel]]” of a website. In ''Blue Nile, Inc. v. Ice.com, Inc.'', the plaintiff sued the defendant for copying the overall “look and feel” of plaintiff’s retail jewelry websites, including the design of plaintiff’s search pages.{{cite web|title=''Blue Nile, Inc. v. Ice.com, Inc.'', 478 F. Supp. 2d 1240 (W.D. Wash., 2007)|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=16544665442853652360|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google|accessdate=12 September 2017}} Although the court ordered more factual development before it could rule definitively on the issue, the court did hold that it was possible for the look and feel of the websites to have trade dress protection if the plaintiff’s copyright claims did not already cover those parts. In ''[[SuicideGirls|SG Services]], Inc. v. [[GodsGirls|God’s Girls]], Inc.'', the court denied trade dress protection for the plaintiff’s website because the plaintiff did not demonstrate that the website was non-functional or distinctive.{{cite web|title=SG Serv., Inc. v. God’s Girls, Inc.'', non-reported case, 2007 WL 2315437 (C.D. Cal. 2007)|url=http://www.websupp.org/data/DOR/3:05-cv-01526-28-DOR.pdf|website=WebsUpp|accessdate=12 September 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705111818/http://www.websupp.org/data/DOR/3:05-cv-01526-28-DOR.pdf|archivedate=5 July 2010}} This case shows the court’s willingness to consider trade dress protection for a website, even though the court did not find protection in this case. It is notable, however, that the ''SG Services'' court did not look at the overall “look and feel” of the website, but rather, at specific characteristics (such as color) of the website that the plaintiff claimed were infringed. Although the future of trade dress protection for websites is still very unclear, much thought has been given to this area and it will likely continue to be actively developing area for courts and litigants.{{cite journal |first=Xuan-Thao N. |last=Nguyen |title=Should it be a Free for All? The Challenge of Extending Trade Dress Protection to the Look and Feel of Web Sites in the Evolving Internet |volume=49 |journal=American University Law Review |issue=6 |pages=1233–1277 |year=2001 |url=http://www.wcl.american.edu/journal/lawrev/49/vol49-6_nguyen.pdf?rd=1 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325123737/https://www.wcl.american.edu/journal/lawrev/49/vol49-6_nguyen.pdf?rd=1 |archivedate=2009-03-25 |df= }} Scott D. Locke, Trade Dress in the Age of E-Commerce: The Challenge of Protecting the “Look and Feel” of Websites and Mobile Apps, 27 Alb. L.J. Sci. & Tech. 213 (2017). http://www.albanylawjournal.org/archives/pages/article-information.aspx?volume=27&issue=3&page=213 ==See also== *[[Geschmacksmuster]] *[[Trademark infringement]] *[[Fashion design copyright]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Trade Dress}} [[Category:Intellectual property law]] [[Category:Trademark law]] {{Trademark law}}
